But when we eat too much of these things, they can make our tummies feel bad or not be good for our bodies over time. Healthy foods, like broccoli or apples, are good for us, but they don’t always taste as exciting. So, it feels like the yummiest foods can be the ones that aren’t so great for us! It’s like a fun game where our taste buds want to party, but we also need to remember to eat things that help us grow strong and feel good.

title: Since Jupiter is 95% hydrogen, could its atmosphere be lit on fire?
text: No, Jupiter's atmosphere can't be lit on fire like a campfire because there's not enough oxygen up there to help it burn. Fire needs three things to happen: fuel (like the hydrogen), heat (like a spark), and oxygen (the stuff we breathe). Even though Jupiter has a lot of hydrogen, which is like rocket fuel, it doesn't have the oxygen needed for a fire to happen. So, even though it sounds like it could catch fire, it's just not possible in the way we think of fire on Earth!

title: How do they produce TV shows so much faster than movies?
text: TV shows are made faster than movies because they have shorter stories to tell and smaller teams working on them. Imagine if you were drawing a big picture; it would take a long time because you have to think of every detail. But if you were drawing a quick comic strip with just a few panels, you could finish it much quicker! TV shows usually have episodes that are around 20 to 30 minutes long, so they can write, film, and edit them faster. Plus, they may use sets and costumes that are already built from previous episodes, which saves a lot of time. So, making lots of quick episodes is kind of like making lots of little drawings instead of one big one!

title: How did Times New Roman become the 'standard' font for typing?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a favorite crayon to use when you draw. Times New Roman is like that favorite crayon for typing! A long time ago, in the 1930s, some really smart people who made newspapers needed a font that was easy to read and looked nice. They created Times New Roman, and it worked really well for printing lots of words on a page. Because it was so good at this, many people started using it for their letters, books, and schoolwork. Over time, it became super popular and everyone just started using it as the standard font, kind of like how everyone loves to use the same crayon in art class! So now, when you type on a computer or print something, Times New Roman is often the font you see because it’s friendly and easy to read, just like your favorite crayon!

title: is sparkling water just as hydrating as plain water?
text: Yes, sparkling water is just as hydrating as plain water! Imagine you have a balloon and you fill it with air; it still holds the same space whether it's regular air or bubbly air. Sparkling water has bubbles in it, which come from carbon dioxide gas, but it still has water inside. So when you drink sparkling water, your body gets the same good stuff it gets from plain water, helping you stay hydrated and feel good! Just remember, some sparkling waters might have added flavors or sugars, so it's good to check those if you want to be super healthy.

title: Why is it often difficult to stay awake while reading, but as soon as you put the book down and try to sleep, you feel wide awake?
text: When you read a book, your brain works hard to understand the words and think about the story, which can make you feel sleepy, kind of like when you listen to a lullaby. But when you stop reading and try to sleep, your brain gets a little confused. It thinks, "Hey, now it's time to be awake!" because it just switched from doing something quiet to trying to rest. So, even though you were sleepy before, now your brain is all excited and doesn’t want to go to sleep yet! It’s like when you play with your toys and then suddenly feel like you have a lot of energy when it’s bedtime.

title: What is the purpose of the turnable dial around the face of a watch?
text: The turnable dial around the face of a watch is called a bezel, and it helps you do things like keep track of time in a different way or measure stuff. For example, if you're swimming and want to know how long you've been in the water, you can turn the bezel to line up with the minute hand. Then, when the minute hand moves, you can see how much time has passed by looking at the numbers on the bezel. Some bezels can even help you count things, like how many laps you've run. So, it's like a little helper on your watch that makes it even more useful!

title: Who/what is Anonymous?
text: Anonymous is like a group of people who wear silly masks and work together on the internet. They don't show their real faces because they want to keep their identities secret. They use computers to share ideas, sometimes help others, and sometimes protest things they think are unfair. Imagine a bunch of superheroes, but instead of capes, they use computers and secret messages to try to make the world a better place or to stand up against things they don’t like.

title: Why do all the planets appear on one horizontal plane in diagrams?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big pizza, and all the toppings (like pepperoni and mushrooms) are spread out on top of the cheese. The pizza is flat, right? Now, think of the planets being like those toppings, but instead of a pizza, they are all moving around the sun in a flat circle called the "solar system." When the solar system was made a long time ago, all the dust and gas swirled around and flattened out like the pizza dough, so most of the planets ended up on that same flat surface. That’s why when we draw them, they all look like they’re on one horizontal line!

title: Why did each (manned) Apollo Mission have a different crew?
text: Each Apollo mission had a different crew because NASA wanted to give many astronauts a chance to go to the Moon and learn how to do space things. Just like how in a school play, you might have different kids playing the same role on different days, NASA picked different astronauts for each mission so they could all have their turn to explore and help with the important work of flying to the Moon. This way, they could learn from each other and make sure everyone was ready for any problems that might happen up there. Plus, it was really exciting for the astronauts to be part of such a cool adventure!

title: When you close your eyes and "look" at the sun, why is it that you see a reddish yellow color even through closed eyes?
text: When you close your eyes and "look" at the sun, your eyelids let some light through, but they also make it a little darker and fuzzy. The bright light from the sun is super strong, and it makes your eyes see colors. The reddish-yellow color is because the sun gives off lots of warm colors, like orange and yellow, and when your eyes are closed, they mix together to look like a soft, warm glow. It’s like when you put a colored piece of paper in front of a bright light; you can still see the light, but it looks different because of the paper!

title: Why do we grunt, yell, swear, ball our fists, grit our teeth, etc. when we're in pain?
text: When we feel pain, it's like our body is sending a big alarm to say, "Ouch! Something's wrong!" Grunting, yelling, or swearing is like when a car honks its horn to get attention. It helps us let out our feelings and shows others that we need help. Balling our fists or gritting our teeth is like trying to be strong and brave, almost like a superhero getting ready to fight the bad guy. Our body does these things naturally to help us handle the pain and get through it, just like how we might cry when we're really sad. It's all part of how we show what we're feeling inside!

title: How does Google Maps and other GPS calculate my estimated time of arrival?
text: Okay! So, imagine you're going to a friend's house, and you want to know how long it will take to get there. Google Maps and GPS are like really smart friends that help you figure that out. They look at a few things: first, they know the distance from where you are to your friend's house, kind of like counting how many steps it takes to walk there. Then, they check how fast you usually go, like if you walk, ride a bike, or drive a car. They also look at what the roads are like, like if there are any bumps or if there’s a lot of traffic, which is when lots of cars are all trying to go at the same time. So, by putting all this information together, they can tell you how long it will take to get to your friend's house, and that’s how they give you the estimated time of arrival, or ETA for short!

title: Why are some redirecting urls like URL_0 just as long as the origanal urls?
text: Okay, imagine you have a really long string of letters and numbers that tells you where to find a fun toy in a big store. This long string is like a URL, which is how we find things on the internet. Now, when someone wants to send you to that toy but makes a new path to get there, they might create a new URL, like "URL_0". Sometimes, this new URL is just as long as the old one because it still needs to have all the important information to get you to the same toy. So, even if it looks different, it might be just as long because it has to carry the same amount of info to get you to the right place!

title: how do computers tell time?
text: Computers tell time like how we use clocks! Inside a computer, there is a special part called a "clock chip" that keeps track of time, just like a tiny clock. This chip counts tiny little ticks, kind of like counting seconds. When you turn on the computer, it looks at this clock chip to know what time it is. It can also connect to the internet to check the time with other computers to make sure it’s right. So, just like you can look at a clock on the wall to see what time it is, a computer checks its own little clock to know the time!

title: How come people can taste substances that have been injected intravenously?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big house with lots of rooms. When you eat or drink something, it goes into your tummy and then gets spread all around the house through a special highway made of blood. Now, when someone puts something in your body through a needle (that’s called injecting), it goes straight into the blood highway. Sometimes, when this happens, the stuff can travel to the part of your body that helps you taste things, which is your tongue and your mouth. Even though you didn’t eat it, your body can sense it and send messages to your brain that say, “Hey, I can taste something!” So, even if it went in a different way, your body still knows how to recognize the flavors.

title: Why is it that some people can climb tall mountains like Mt. Everest without oxygen, but most people can't?
text: Some people can climb really tall mountains like Mt. Everest without oxygen because their bodies are special and can handle less air better than most people. You see, when you go up high, like on a mountain, there’s less air to breathe, which means less oxygen. Some climbers train their bodies to get used to this by practicing at high places for a long time, so their hearts and lungs become super strong and can work better with less oxygen. They also have a special way of breathing and staying calm. Most people, like you and me, need more oxygen to feel good and do things, so when we go up high, we might feel dizzy or very tired. That's why we usually need extra oxygen to help us when we climb really tall mountains!

title: Why are the health benefits of sunlight not replicated by other light sources?
text: Okay, imagine the sun is like a big, warm lamp in the sky that gives us special light. This light is super important because it helps our bodies make something called Vitamin D, which keeps our bones strong and helps us feel happy. Other light sources, like light bulbs, don’t have the same kind of special rays that the sun has. They might help us see in the dark, but they don’t help our bodies the same way the sun does. It’s like how a regular toy can’t do the special things a superhero toy can do! So, we need some sunlight to be healthy and feel good, and that’s why we can’t get all those health benefits from other lights.

title: what's the difference between triple A games and other types of games?
text: Okay, imagine you have two types of toys: one is a super cool, shiny robot that has lots of buttons and lights, and it comes in a big box with colorful pictures. This robot is made by a big company that spends a lot of time and money to make it really awesome. That's like a "triple A" game! These games are made by big teams with lots of money, and they're usually really fun, look great, and have lots of things to do. Now, the other type of toy is a simple little car that you can make at home with some cardboard and markers. It might be fun, but it doesn't have all the fancy stuff that the robot has. That's like other types of games, which can be made by smaller teams or by just one person. They might be really creative and fun too, but they don't have the same polish or big budgets as triple A games. So, the main difference is how much time, money, and people are involved in making them!

title: Why are aquariums lit by blue lights?
text: Aquariums are often lit by blue lights because it makes the water and the fish look really pretty! Blue light helps to bring out the colors of fish and plants, making them look brighter and more colorful. It also looks nice because it reminds us of the ocean, where fish live. Plus, some fish like certain types of light better, and blue light is gentle on their eyes. So, using blue lights helps us see the fish better and keeps them happy too!

title: If fevers are part of our body's natural process to fighting off infection / viruses, why do we often take medication to take away the fever?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a superhero team that fights bad guys, like germs and viruses. When these bad guys come to attack, your body raises its temperature to fight them off, kind of like turning up the heat to make it harder for them to survive. This is called a fever! It's a good thing because it helps your body heal. But sometimes, the fever can make you feel really yucky, like super hot, tired, or achy, and it's hard to play or eat. So, people take medicine, like fever reducers, to help lower the temperature and make them feel better. It's like turning down the heat in your house so you can be comfy while the superhero team gets rid of the bad guys. Even with the medicine, your body is still working hard to fight off the germs!

title: What is Altitude Sickness and why do people get it?
text: Altitude sickness is when your body feels sick because you go up really high, like on a tall mountain. When you're up high, there is less air, and that means less oxygen, which is the special stuff we breathe that helps us feel good and have energy. So, when people go up high too fast, their bodies can get confused and not get enough oxygen. This can make them feel dizzy, tired, or give them a headache, kind of like when you spin around too much and feel funny. To help, people can go up slower or take breaks to let their bodies get used to the higher place.

title: Why are birds (i.e. Parrots, Crows, Hawks, etc) so intelligent if they have such small brains?
text: Birds are really smart because of how their brains work, not just how big they are! Even though their brains are small, they have a lot of special parts that help them think, learn, and remember things. It's kind of like having a tiny computer that runs super fast! Birds like parrots and crows can solve puzzles, use tools, and even talk because their brains have a lot of connections that help them understand the world around them. So, it's not about the size of the brain, but how well it can do things!

title: Why do some foods taste better cold and some hot? Is it strictly cultural, or are certain tastes more apt to be pleasurable at a certain temperature biologically?
text: Some foods taste better cold and some taste better hot because of how our taste buds and noses work. When food is hot, certain smells and flavors can be stronger, like pizza or soup, making them extra yummy. Cold foods, like ice cream or leftovers from the fridge, can be refreshing and sometimes taste sweeter or more crunchy, like a cold apple. It's not just about culture; it's also because our bodies can enjoy different tastes at different temperatures. So, it's kind of like how some toys are fun to play with outside and some are fun to play with inside; different foods just like to be at their best at different temperatures!

title: How does 20th Century Fox, Universal, Sony Pictures and Lionsgate own rights to some of Marvel's characters in film even though Marvel made those characters originally?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of toys, and you made some really cool action figures that you love. Now, let's say you let your friends borrow some of those toys to play with. Your friend Universal really liked one of your action figures, so you said they could use it in their games, but only for a little while. So, even though you created the toy, your friend gets to use it for their fun. That's kind of like what happened with Marvel. A long time ago, they let other companies like 20th Century Fox, Universal, Sony Pictures, and Lionsgate use some of their characters for movies, but Marvel still owns the characters. It's like sharing your toys, but each friend gets to play with their favorite ones in their own way!

title: How were the values of constants such as e and pi historically determined, and why do these constants find themselves in so many formulae?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a really big pizza, and you want to know how big the pizza is all around. The number that helps you figure out the distance around the pizza is called pi (π), and it’s about 3.14. A long time ago, people used to measure round things, like circles, and they noticed that no matter how big the circle was, if you took the distance around it and divided it by how straight it is across the middle, you always got about 3.14. That’s how they found out what pi is! Now, let’s talk about e. It’s a special number that helps us understand things that grow or shrink, like money or plants. People discovered e by looking at how things change over time, and it’s about 2.71. Both pi and e are like secret codes that help us solve puzzles in math, and that’s why you see them in lots of different math problems and formulas, just like how you can use different toppings to make all sorts of yummy pizzas!

title: How does working out in the morning give us *more* energy through out the day when our body is using energy to work out?
text: When you work out in the morning, it's like giving your body a nice wake-up call, just like how you feel more awake after a good night's sleep! When you exercise, your heart starts pumping faster, and your blood moves around your body better, which helps you feel more awake and happy. Even though your muscles are using energy to move, your body gets stronger and learns to use energy more efficiently. After you finish working out, your body feels proud and releases special chemicals that make you feel good and full of energy, almost like a superhero! So, even if you used some energy to exercise, you end up feeling more energetic and ready to play or learn the rest of the day!

title: How is the ink permanantly sticking onto the paper but can be erased from the hand?
text: Okay, imagine you have a magic marker and a piece of paper. When you draw on the paper, the ink soaks into it and sticks really well, kind of like how a sponge holds water. This makes the drawing hard to wipe off because the paper is like a sponge that keeps the ink. But when you accidentally get some ink on your hand, it doesn’t stick as well because your skin is smooth and slippery, so you can wash it off with soap and water. So, the ink likes to stay on the paper, but it can slide right off your skin!

title: Why do tennis players use stationary cycle right after a match?
text: Tennis players use stationary bikes right after a match to help their bodies feel better and recover faster. When they play, their muscles get tired and sometimes feel stiff, like when you run around a lot and your legs get wobbly. Riding a bike gently helps their muscles relax and get rid of bad stuff called lactic acid that makes them sore. It’s like giving their legs a nice, gentle hug to help them feel good again! Plus, it keeps their heart pumping and helps them cool down, so they can be ready to play again soon.

title: How do fishermen on those large trawlers with nets catch the exact fish they are looking for?
text: Okay, imagine you have a really big fishing net that you can throw in the water. Fishermen on big boats, called trawlers, do something similar but with special nets. They know where certain fish like to swim, so they go to those spots. The nets have different sizes of holes, which helps catch some fish but lets smaller ones swim away. They also use special tools and gadgets to find out where the fish are swimming. Sometimes, they even use bright lights to attract the fish. So, when they throw the net in the water, it catches the fish they want while letting the little ones go free. It's like using a big scoop to catch just the right toys in a toy box!

title: Joyful people are said to have a twinkle in their eyes, what physically changes in a depressed or sad person's eyes to create the "dead eye" effect?
text: When someone is really happy, their eyes might look bright and shiny, almost like they have a little sparkle or twinkle in them. This happens because their brain sends happy signals that can make their body feel good, and that includes their eyes. But when someone is sad or depressed, their brain isn't sending those happy signals. This can make their eyes look dull and less shiny, like they don’t have much light or energy in them. They might also look a bit tired or have less color, which is why we sometimes say they have "dead eyes." It's like if a toy runs out of batteries; it stops glowing and just looks kind of flat.

title: Why does a real person who is speaking right next to me sound so different from a person on TV, apparently speaking right in front of me?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy that makes sounds, like a little speaker. When a real person talks next to you, their voice goes straight to your ears like a little wave, and you can hear their voice clearly. But when you watch a person on TV, their voice travels through the TV first, and then comes out of the speakers. The TV adds different sounds and sometimes even makes the voice sound a bit funny, like when you put a funny filter on a picture. Plus, the person on TV is usually on a screen and not right in front of you, so it feels like they are further away. That's why they sound different from someone talking right next to you!

title: Why Do We Tend To Notice Things in Pairs? Or, why does there seem to be a general consensus that even numbers are more, "attractive"?
text: Okay, imagine you have a box of crayons. If you have one red crayon, it’s nice, but if you have two red crayons, it just looks better, right? This is because our brains like things that are balanced and even, like pairs, because they make us feel more comfortable and happy. It’s sort of like how two eyes help us see better than just one. When things are in pairs, they feel like friends and make a nicer picture! So, when we see things in even numbers, like two apples or four chairs, it feels more pleasing to us, like a cozy hug! That’s why even numbers seem more attractive!

title: Why does Rorschach hate Veidt's Plan while likes Truman's Hiroshima Bombing?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a toy box and you want to keep all your toys safe. Rorschach is like a superhero who really cares about people being safe and doing the right thing. He doesn't like Veidt's Plan because it makes a lot of people scared and hurt, even if it was meant to stop a big fight. He thinks that’s wrong, like if someone took your toys and broke them to make everyone play nice. But when it comes to the Hiroshima Bombing, Rorschach sees it differently. He believes that it ended a big war and saved more lives in the end, kind of like when you finish a big game quickly so everyone can go home and play later. So, Rorschach likes that it helped stop the fighting, but he hates Veidt's Plan because it hurts too many people to make peace.

title: What is a Health Savings Account?
text: A Health Savings Account, or HSA, is like a special piggy bank that you can use to save money for doctor visits and medicine when you get sick. You can put money in this piggy bank before you pay your taxes, which means you can save a little extra. The money you put in can be used to pay for things like visits to the doctor, medicine, or even a hospital stay. The cool part is that if you don’t use all the money in your piggy bank, it can stay there and even grow bigger over time, just like a plant growing in a garden! This way, when you really need it, you’ll have enough money saved up to help you feel better.

title: How exactly did OJ Simpson get a not guilty verdict? The evidence seemed insurmountable
text: Okay, imagine you have a box of toys, and someone says you broke a toy. They find your fingerprints all over it, and there are even pictures of you near the toy when it broke. But when you go to a big meeting where people decide if you’re guilty or not, you have a really good friend who helps you. This friend says, “Wait! Maybe the fingerprints were put there by accident, and maybe the pictures aren’t clear!” So, during the meeting, they talk a lot about how the evidence isn’t perfect, and they even find some mistakes in how the people checked the toys. In the end, the people at the meeting decided that they weren’t sure you really broke the toy, so they said you didn’t have to be punished. That’s kind of how OJ Simpson got a not guilty verdict – there was a lot of talk about the evidence not being strong enough, even if it looked like he might be guilty at first.

title: what is a superfluid?
text: A superfluid is like a magical kind of liquid that can flow without getting stopped, kind of like if you had a slippery slide that never slowed you down! Imagine if you poured some water and it just kept going and going without ever getting tired or bumping into things. Superfluids can move around really easily, even if there are no walls to help them, and they can do cool things like climb up the sides of a container or flow through tiny spaces without losing any energy. It's a special state of matter that happens when things get super cold, like way colder than ice cream!

title: Why do we pee our beds as kids, but not as adults?
text: Okay, so when we are little kids, sometimes we pee our beds because our bodies are still learning how to control when we go to the bathroom. It’s like when you’re learning to ride a bike; you might fall a few times until you get really good at it. Our bladders, which are like little balloons that hold our pee, need time to grow and learn when to tell us it’s time to go. As we get older, our brains and bodies get better at talking to each other, so we wake up when we need to go to the bathroom. That’s why most grown-ups don’t pee their beds anymore!

title: Why are US congress member's allowed to retain their private careers and other outside business interests while serving the government?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy box full of different toys. Some toys are your favorites that you play with all the time, and others are toys you only take out sometimes. Now, think of Congress members like people who have to keep playing with their favorite toys (which is their job in the government) but also want to play with some of their other toys (which are their private jobs or businesses). The rules say they can keep playing with both because it helps them understand what people need. But, just like you have to share your toys and play nicely with friends, Congress members have to be careful and not let their other jobs mess up their important work for everyone. It’s like making sure that sharing your toys doesn’t lead to any fights! So, they need to be honest and make sure they don’t let their private interests get in the way of helping everyone in the country.

title: Why does honey sometimes crystallise and go 'hard' in the jar?
text: Honey can sometimes turn hard and look like it's full of little crystals because it has sugar in it, and that sugar can come together to make crystals, just like how you can make rock candy from sugar water. When honey is stored in a cool place or if it has some tiny bits of pollen or other stuff in it, it can encourage the sugar to start making crystals. This is normal and doesn't mean the honey is bad! If you want to make it soft again, you can warm it up a little by putting the jar in warm water, and the crystals will go away. So, crystallized honey is just honey that is having a little sugar party!

title: What does a virus or bacteria gain from making its host sick?
text: Okay, imagine that a virus or bacteria is like a tiny little monster that wants to eat and make more tiny monsters like itself. When it gets into your body, it makes you sick because that's how it can find food and a nice warm place to live. When you have a cold or the flu, your body is working hard to fight off the monster, but while it’s doing that, the monster is busy using your energy and resources to grow and make more of itself. So, by making you sick, the monster gets what it needs to survive and spread to other people, kind of like how a plant needs sunlight and water to grow!

title: What is a "sigh," exactly, and why do we do it when we're sad or exasperated? Does every culture sigh?
text: A "sigh" is when you take a big breath in and then let it out slowly, like you're blowing air out of a balloon. We often sigh when we feel sad, tired, or frustrated because it helps us feel a little better, like letting out all the heavy feelings inside. It’s like giving our body a little hug to say, “It’s okay.” People in many different cultures sigh too, but sometimes they might do it in different ways or for different reasons. It’s a way our bodies speak to show how we feel without using words!

title: Why does a flight from London to Italy(2500km) cost about $70...but a flight from New York to Atlanta(800km) costs about $250 ?
text: Okay! So, think of flights like a big game where people want to go places. When lots of people want to go from one place to another, like London to Italy, the airplane companies make the tickets cheaper to fill up the seats. It’s like having a big party and you want all your friends to come, so you make it easy for them! But when not as many people want to go from New York to Atlanta, the companies can make the tickets more expensive because they know there are fewer seats being sold. Plus, the distance isn’t the only thing that matters; sometimes there are more costs for the planes, the airports, and how many people are flying. So, it's like if you wanted to sell cookies: if lots of kids want cookies, you charge less to sell more, but if only a few kids want them, you might charge more!

title: There's plenty of cow milk to buy, and some goat milk, but is there's a reason we don't produce and consume milk from other farm animals (like horses, pigs, etc)? What about cheese made from that milk?
text: Okay, so you know how we drink cow milk and sometimes goat milk? That's because cows and goats make a lot of milk that's really yummy and good for us. Other animals, like horses and pigs, don't make as much milk, and their milk doesn’t taste as good or is not as healthy for us to drink. Horses make milk, but it’s kind of different and not many people like it. Pigs also don’t make milk that people usually drink because it’s really thick and not tasty. When it comes to cheese, we usually want milk that’s easy to turn into cheese, and cow and goat milk are really good for that. So, while you can make cheese from other kinds of milk, it just doesn’t taste as good or is hard to make, which is why we mostly stick with cow and goat milk for our drinks and cheese!

title: How do eyeglasses fix our vision?
text: Eyeglasses help us see better because they change the way light comes into our eyes. Imagine your eyes are like a camera that needs to focus to take a clear picture. Sometimes, the camera doesn't focus right, so everything looks blurry. Eyeglasses have special glass that helps focus the light correctly, kind of like a magic window that makes everything clear again. When you put on your glasses, they guide the light so your eyes can see things sharply and clearly, just like a camera that has the right lens!

title: Why are Americans so worried about losing jobs to other countries when their unemployment is at 4.5%?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy store, and you sell toys to kids in your neighborhood. Now, what if another toy store in another country sells the same toys, but for much cheaper because they can make them for less money? Some kids might start buying from that store instead of yours. Even if you have a lot of kids coming to your store (like having a low unemployment rate), you still worry because if too many kids go to the other store, you might have to close your store and lose your job. So, even when lots of people have jobs, Americans worry that if companies start buying toys (or making things) from other countries, it might make some people lose their jobs. They want to keep their jobs safe, just like you would want to keep your toy store open!

title: How does the UK justify that they have a reasonable claim over the Falkland Islands?
text: The UK believes they have a good reason to say the Falkland Islands belong to them because they have been in charge of the islands for a long time. A long time ago, in the 1700s, British people started living there, and the UK made it a part of their country. They also think that the people who live there now, who are mostly British, want to stay with the UK and not be part of another country. So, the UK says they have a right to keep the islands because of their long history and because the people there want to be British.

title: Why does it take so long for death row inmates to be executed?
text: It takes a long time for death row inmates to be executed because there are a lot of important steps to make sure everything is fair and correct. Imagine if someone said you did something really bad, and you had to wait a long time to prove you didn't do it. First, there are many people who check the case to make sure the right person is being punished, like lawyers and judges. Then, there are rules and laws that have to be followed, and sometimes people appeal or ask to have their case looked at again, which can take years. Also, some people think it's not right to use the death penalty, so they want to make sure everything is done carefully. This is all to help make sure no one gets hurt by making a mistake. So, just like how we take our time to make sure a game is played fairly, the same happens with death row to make sure justice is served properly.

title: Why is it colder at higher altitudes even though hot air rises?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big jar of honey and you know how the top part is warm and the bottom part is cold. When you go higher up, like climbing a mountain, the air gets thinner, which means there aren’t as many air particles squished together. Hot air is lighter and likes to rise, but as it goes up, it spreads out because there’s less air pressing down on it. So, when you climb higher, the air gets colder because it’s not as squished together and it can’t hold onto the heat as well. That’s why the top of a mountain can be chilly, even though hot air likes to go up!

title: how do big hotels keep their showers so hot and high pressured?
text: Big hotels have really smart systems to make sure their showers are super hot and have lots of water pressure. They use big water heaters that can heat up lots of water really fast, like how a kettle boils water for tea. These heaters are connected to pipes that bring water to all the showers in the hotel. They also have strong pumps that push the water through the pipes quickly, so when you turn on the shower, the water comes out fast and feels like a nice, warm rain. Plus, hotels have special valves and controls to make sure the temperature is just right, so you can enjoy a nice hot shower whenever you want!

title: If water and ice both have transparent properties, why is snow white?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big pile of tiny ice crystals, like really, really small pieces of ice. When light hits these tiny pieces, they bounce around all over the place, kind of like how a ball bounces off the walls in a room. Since the light is bouncing everywhere, it doesn’t just go straight through like it does with clear water or ice. Instead, all that light mixes together and looks white to our eyes. So, even though ice and water are clear, when they come together as lots of tiny ice crystals in snow, they make it look white!

title: Given that x-rays have more energy than visible light and radiowaves have less energy than visible light, how come visible light can't penetrate walls but x-rays and radiowaves can?
text: Okay, imagine light is like a team of tiny, invisible superheroes. Each type of light has its own special powers. X-rays are like superheroes with super strength, so they can smash through walls and peek inside things, like a doctor looking at your bones. Visible light is like regular superheroes; they are strong enough to help us see, but they can't break through walls because they aren’t strong enough. Radio waves are like superheroes that are really, really good at sneaking around; they can slip through walls, but they don’t have the power to help us see things. So, even though X-rays are super strong and radio waves can sneak, visible light doesn’t have the right powers to go through walls!

title: If the Keystone Pipeline is approved, but the US withdraws from NAFTA, what will this mean in terms of oil trade through the pipeline?
text: Okay, imagine the Keystone Pipeline is like a big slide that helps oil go from one place to another, kind of like how you slide down to get to the bottom of a playground slide. Now, NAFTA is like a set of rules that helps the people in the playground share their toys easily, in this case, oil, between the U.S., Canada, and Mexico. If the Keystone Pipeline gets the green light to work, it means oil can go down the slide. But if the U.S. decides to stop playing by the NAFTA rules, it might make it a little trickier for them to share oil with their friends in Canada and Mexico. So, while the pipeline can still work, the way oil is traded and how easy or hard it is to do that might change, like having to ask permission every time you want to use a toy.

title: Why is quartz so useful in making watches?
text: Quartz is really useful for making watches because it's like a tiny magic rock that can help tell time super accurately! Inside a quartz watch, there's a special piece of quartz crystal. When you put a battery in the watch, it sends electricity to the crystal, and the crystal starts to vibrate very quickly, like when you shake a toy. These vibrations happen exactly the same way every time, which helps the watch keep track of seconds, minutes, and hours. So, thanks to quartz, we can have watches that are really good at knowing what time it is, and they don’t need to be wound up like some old-fashioned watches!

title: Why do women's breasts get bigger before they have their period?
text: Okay, so you know how sometimes your body changes a little bit? Well, before a girl gets her period, her body gets ready for it, kind of like getting ready for a big party! One of the things that happens is that her breasts can get bigger or feel a bit fuller. This is because her body is making special chemicals called hormones that help it prepare for the possibility of having a baby someday. These hormones can make the tissues in the breasts swell up a little, just like a sponge gets bigger when you put it in water. So, it's all just part of how a girl's body works as it gets ready for that time of the month!

title: What is the recent ruling about the UK Parliament and Brexit mean for the people of the UK?
text: Okay, so imagine the UK is like a big clubhouse that used to play with a lot of other clubhouses in Europe. When they decided they didn't want to play with those other clubhouses anymore, it was called Brexit. A recent ruling means that the people in charge of the clubhouse, called Parliament, have to make some important choices about how they say goodbye to the other clubhouses. This could change how the people in the UK get things like toys and snacks from Europe, and it might also change how they can go to visit their friends in those clubhouses. So, for the people in the UK, it means they might notice some differences in what they can buy and where they can travel, but the grown-ups are trying to figure it all out to make sure everyone is okay!

title: Can the POTUS issue Executive Order on withdrawing from NATO?
text: No, the President of the United States (POTUS) can't just say, "We're done with NATO!" by using an Executive Order. NATO is a group of countries that work together for safety, and it's like a big promise between friends to help each other. To leave NATO, the President would need to follow some special rules, kind of like how you can't just quit a game you were playing with your friends without talking to them first. The President would have to tell Congress, which is like the team that helps make big decisions, and they would need to agree on how to do it. So, it's not something the President can decide all alone.

title: What causes those random shudders that happen seemingly for no reason?
text: Those random shudders you feel, like when your body suddenly shakes or jerks a little, are called "hypnic jerks." They usually happen when you're just about to fall asleep. Imagine you're a toy winding down, and sometimes you might make a little jump or twitch as you stop moving. It's your body's way of saying, "Hey, I'm getting sleepy!" Sometimes it happens if you're really tired or if you're thinking about a lot of things before bed. It’s totally normal and nothing to worry about!

title: What is Net Neutrality and why is there a lot of controversy surrounding it?
text: Net neutrality is like having rules that say all the toys in a big toy box should be shared equally, so everyone gets to play with whatever they want without anyone being mean. In this case, the toys are websites and the internet. If there are no rules (no net neutrality), some companies might make it so only certain websites work really well, like making their favorite toys bigger and shinier, while other websites might be slow or hard to find, like making those toys really small and dusty. This makes people upset because they want to make sure everyone can enjoy all the websites equally, just like everyone should be able to play with all the toys in the toy box without anyone being unfair. That's why there's a lot of arguing about it!

title: There are a surprising amount of people who believe any moon landings were a hoax. Why can't we use telescopes/powerful cameras to prove there was activity on the moon?
text: Okay, imagine the moon is like a big ball in the sky that’s really far away, like how far away your friend's house is when you can’t see it even if you try really hard. Even though we have really strong telescopes and cameras, they still can’t see tiny things on the moon, like footprints or the little flags that were left there. It’s because the moon is super far away and even big things look really tiny from that far. Plus, the best telescopes can see really cool stuff in space, but they can't zoom in enough to see those little details. Scientists have other ways to prove we went to the moon, like pictures taken by spaceships that went there, special rocks brought back from the moon, and even the fact that we can bounce lasers off special mirrors left on the moon. So, while we can’t just use a camera to show tiny things, we have lots of other proof that we really did go to the moon!

title: What makes blue ink more memorable than black ink?
text: Imagine you have a box of crayons, and you really like to use the color blue because it’s bright and fun. When you write something with blue ink, it stands out and feels special, just like your favorite crayon! Our brains notice things that are different or unusual more easily, so when we see blue ink instead of the usual black ink, it grabs our attention and helps us remember what was written better. It’s like when you see a blue butterfly instead of a brown one; the blue butterfly is more exciting and sticks in your mind!

title: Why would you ever need to know the anything beyond the 2nd derivative of an equation?
text: Okay, imagine you’re riding a bike on a smooth road. The first derivative tells us how fast you’re going, like your speed. The second derivative tells us if you’re speeding up or slowing down, like if you’re going downhill (going faster) or uphill (going slower). Now, sometimes, we want to know even more about how your ride feels! The third derivative can tell us if your speed is changing quickly or slowly, like if you suddenly hit a bump or if the road gets really smooth. And the fourth derivative can help us understand if that bump feels big or small. So, knowing about the third and fourth derivatives helps us understand not just how fast you’re going but also how the ride changes over time, which can be really important when planning to go fast or safe!

title: when muscles get stronger they grow. How do our lungs get stronger if you go for a long run?
text: Okay, so imagine your lungs are like balloons. When you run a lot, your body needs more air, just like how a balloon needs to be blown up to be big. When you practice running, your lungs learn to take in more air and get better at using it, kind of like how you can stretch a balloon to make it bigger. So, the more you run, the stronger your lungs get at taking in air and giving you energy, just like a balloon gets bigger when you blow it up more!

title: Why is it important to preheat the oven before you cook?
text: Preheating the oven is like warming up before you play a game or do a race. When you warm up, your body gets ready, and you can play better. The oven needs to get hot before you put your food in so it cooks properly and evenly. If you put your food in a cold oven, it might not cook all the way through, or it could take a lot longer than it should. So, preheating helps your food bake just right, like how warming up helps you do your best when you play!

title: Why can't touchscreens recognize a touch while a finger is being held on it in another location?
text: Okay, imagine a touchscreen is like a big, flat piece of magic paper that can feel your fingers. When you touch it, it knows where you are touching because it has special sensors inside. Now, if you touch one spot and then try to touch another spot while still holding the first finger down, the magic paper gets a little confused. It’s like if you were trying to hold two balloons at the same time with one hand; it can only pay attention to one balloon at a time! So, the touchscreen usually only listens to your first touch and ignores the second one until you lift your finger off the first spot. That’s why it can’t recognize your touch in a new place while you’re still touching somewhere else!

title: Who physically writes out things like Executive Orders?
text: Executive Orders are special instructions from the President of the United States, kind of like when a teacher gives a special note to the class. While the President decides what to say in the order, there are people called staff or assistants who actually write it down. They make sure it sounds just right and follows the rules. So, it's like when you tell a friend what to write, and they help you put it on paper!

title: How did universities and hospitals and such charge so little for services in the past and still turn a profit when they struggle today even charging so much?
text: A long time ago, universities and hospitals didn't have to spend as much money on things like fancy buildings, new technology, or paying their workers a lot. They also got help from the government and donations from people who wanted to support education and health. This meant they could charge less for classes and medical care and still make enough money to stay open. Nowadays, everything costs more, like paying workers better, keeping up with new machines, and fixing buildings, so they have to charge more to cover those costs. It’s like if you used to buy candy for a quarter, but now it costs a dollar because the store has to pay more to keep the lights on and pay the nice people who work there.

title: How does rolling upon impact with the ground after a long fall save you from bodily harm?
text: When you fall from a high place, your body goes really fast, and it can hurt a lot when you hit the ground. But if you roll when you land, it helps spread out the bump instead of just hitting one part of your body really hard. Imagine if you were rolling on the grass; if you roll, you land on your back, your side, or your legs instead of just your feet or knees. This makes the fall feel softer and helps keep you from getting hurt as much because your body is moving in a way that shares the impact. It's like when you jump on a trampoline and land on your butt instead of your feet; it feels much better! So, rolling helps keep you safe by making the fall less tough on your body.

title: Why is it that a 10 minute 720p video I record with my phone is 700mb, yet a 720p 1.5 hour long movie uses less data?
text: Okay, so think of video like a big box of crayons. When you record a video with your phone, it uses a lot of crayons to make the picture look really nice and clear, which takes up a lot of space in the box. Your 10-minute video is like using a whole bunch of crayons for just a short drawing, so it fills up the box a lot. Now, for the movie, even though it’s longer, it’s like the movie makers used special magic crayons that don’t take up as much space but still look good. They know how to pack the colors in a way that saves space in the box, so the long movie takes less room even though it plays for a long time! So, your phone video uses more space because it’s using more details and is not as good at saving space as the movie.

title: How does an air fryer work?
text: An air fryer is like a little oven that cooks food really fast by blowing hot air around it! Imagine you have a toy that you want to dry off quickly; if you blow on it with a straw, it dries faster because the air moves around it. An air fryer has a fan inside that blows hot air all around the food, kind of like that, and it makes the outside crispy, like when you fry something in oil, but without using much oil. So, you can make yummy things like fries or chicken that taste delicious and are a little bit healthier too!

title: In the age of computers, why do traffic cops take ages to write a traffic ticket by hand? Why not have the system that scans your drivers license and creates a ticket for the next available court date?
text: Traffic cops often write tickets by hand because they have a special way of doing things that keeps them focused and careful. Even though computers are super fast, not all places have the same technology, and sometimes it's easier to just use paper when they are out on the street. If they use a computer, it needs to work perfectly and be connected to the internet, which isn't always possible. Also, writing tickets by hand helps the officer pay more attention to the situation and the person they are talking to. Plus, sometimes the computers can be slow or have problems, and it’s helpful to have a backup plan. But many places are starting to use better technology, so in the future, writing tickets might become quicker and easier!

title: How are syringe needles made?
text: Syringe needles are made in a special way to make sure they are sharp and safe. First, they start with a long, thin piece of metal called a tube. Then, machines help to cut and shape the metal into a very tiny point, like a little arrow. After that, the needle is cleaned to make sure it’s safe to use. Finally, they put the needle onto a plastic part called a syringe, which holds the medicine. So, it’s like making a tiny arrow that helps doctors give medicine to people!

title: Who is Ajit Pai and why is he such a threat to net neutrality?
text: Ajit Pai is a man who used to be in charge of something called the FCC, which helps decide the rules for how the internet works. Net neutrality is like a rule that says all websites should be treated the same, so you can visit any site you want without one being faster or slower than another. Some people think Ajit Pai is a threat to net neutrality because he wanted to change those rules, which could allow big companies to make some websites faster and others slower, kind of like a race where only the really fast cars can win. This made many people worried that it wouldn't be fair for everyone using the internet.

title: How can I know if a News Source is biased or providing 'Alternative Facts'?
text: Okay, imagine you have a box of crayons, and each crayon is a different color. Some crayons are bright and cheerful, while others might be dark and scary. News sources are like those crayons; some tell stories that make things seem really good or really bad, depending on how they feel about it. To see if a news source is biased or telling 'alternative facts,' you can do a few things. First, check if they show both sides of a story. If they only talk about one side, like only the cheerful or only the scary crayons, they might be hiding the whole picture. Second, look for the evidence they use – if they say something is true but don’t show where they got that information, be careful! It’s like saying you saw a unicorn but not showing a picture. Lastly, try reading other news sources too, like trying different flavors of ice cream. If a lot of them say the same thing, it’s probably more true. But if only one source says something really different, it might be a little bit like a tall tale. So, just like picking the right crayon for your picture, picking the right news source helps you see things clearly!

title: If the Earth experienced heating and cooling all the time before humans were around, what triggered the switch to cooling when it got too hot and heating when it got to cold all on its own and why won't that happen with the current climate changes?
text: Okay, imagine the Earth is like a big playground with a seesaw. Sometimes the seesaw tips one way, and the Earth gets hotter, like when you jump on one side. Other times, it tips the other way, and the Earth gets cooler, like when you jump off. This happens because of things like the sun shining differently, volcanoes blowing up, and even big rocks from space hitting the Earth. These changes are like the kids playing on the seesaw! Now, in the past, nature had a way of balancing things out, like if one side got too high, something would happen to bring it back down, just like friends helping each other on a seesaw. But now, with people using cars, factories, and cutting down trees, we're putting a lot of extra heat into the playground, which is like jumping on the seesaw too much on one side. So, it's harder for nature to bring things back to normal because we have changed the game. That's why the Earth might not cool down like it used to when it gets too hot; it needs help from everyone to fix it!

title: Why, when you get a "oh crap I have to pee now moment", does the feeling get worse the closer you get to the toilet?
text: Okay, imagine your bladder is like a balloon filling up with water. When it gets really full, it sends a message to your brain saying, "Hey! We need to go to the bathroom!" Now, when you start walking to the toilet, your brain gets excited because it knows you're almost there, and it thinks, "Yay! Relief is coming!" But as you get closer, it's like the balloon is getting even tighter, and your brain starts to feel extra urgency because it knows it's really time to go. So, the closer you get to the toilet, the more your brain reminds you how badly you need to pee, making that feeling even stronger until you finally can go!

title: How is this light effect created in 90s cartoon animation?
text: In 90s cartoon animation, light effects were made to look cool and pretty by using a special trick. When animators drew the pictures, they would add bright colors or shiny spots to show where the light was hitting things, like a shiny sun or a glowing magical object. They would also use different shades of colors to make things look lighter or darker, just like how shadows work in real life. Sometimes they would even add sparkling effects to make it seem magical! All of this was done by hand, so it took a lot of time and care to make everything look just right.

title: Why are our eyes spherical?
text: Our eyes are shaped like little balls or spheres because this shape helps them work better. Imagine a ball that can roll in all directions; it's super good at moving around. Our eyes need to see in many directions, and being round helps them do that. Also, the round shape helps to focus light, which is what we need to see things clearly. Just like how a smooth ball rolls easily, our round eyes help us look around and see more of the world without any trouble!

title: What protects The United States from becoming a dictatorship?
text: The United States has a special set of rules called the Constitution, which is like a big instruction book for how the country should work. It says that the government has to share power and listen to the people. There are three branches of government: the President, who is like the boss; Congress, which makes the laws; and the courts, which make sure the laws are fair. They all check on each other to make sure no one gets too powerful, kind of like how you and your friends take turns to make sure everyone gets a chance to play. Plus, people can vote to choose their leaders and change things if they don’t like how things are going, which helps keep the government from becoming a dictatorship, where one person has all the power and doesn’t listen to anyone else. So, it's like having rules in a game that keep it fair and fun for everyone!

title: Why is the 40-yard dash the magical number for gauging a football player's speed (as opposed to some other metric)?
text: The 40-yard dash is like a special race that helps people see how fast a football player can run, kind of like how we measure how fast you can run from one end of the playground to the other. It's 40 yards long because that distance is really good for showing off speed in football, where players often need to sprint quickly. It’s not too short, so it shows real speed, but it’s not too long, so players can still give their best effort. Everyone uses the same distance, so it’s like all players are playing the same game, making it easy to compare who is the fastest. That’s why the 40-yard dash is like the magic number for measuring speed in football!

title: Why are clouds flat on the bottom or appear this way?
text: Clouds look flat on the bottom because that's where the water droplets inside them start to form. Imagine a big sponge soaking up water – when it gets full, the water drips out from the bottom. In the sky, when warm air rises, it cools down and can hold less water, so the water turns into tiny droplets and starts to gather together. This happens at the same height, which makes the bottom of the cloud look flat. So, it’s like a big, fluffy blanket that has a straight edge at the bottom because all the little water drops are huddling together there!

title: Your net worth is a billion. Where do you get your spending money?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big treasure chest full of gold coins, and that treasure chest is worth a billion dollars! Now, you don’t want to take all the coins out at once because then your chest would be empty. So, instead, you take a little bit of money out to spend whenever you need it, like buying toys or candy. This money usually comes from the things you own that are valuable, like your house or businesses. When those things make money, it’s like finding more coins! So, even though you have a billion dollars, you just take out a little bit at a time to use for spending.

title: How does our brain "edit out" our nose from our line of sight?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big toy in front of you, like a teddy bear. When you look at the teddy bear, you can see it really well, but if you look down, you can see your nose too! But your brain is super smart and knows you already see your nose all the time, so it "edits" it out so you can focus better on the teddy bear. It’s like when you’re watching your favorite cartoon, and you don’t notice the toy box next to you because you’re so focused on the screen. Your brain helps you pay attention to what really matters and makes things that aren’t important disappear from your view!

title: Is it true that smoke from incense and candles is more harmful than cigarette smoke?
text: Okay, imagine when you light a candle or burn some incense, they make smoke that goes into the air. This smoke can have tiny bits that aren't good for your lungs, like how cigarette smoke has bad stuff too. Some studies say that the smoke from incense and candles can sometimes be worse for you than cigarette smoke because it can have more of those tiny bits, especially if you burn them a lot in a small room. But it's important to remember that all smoke is not good for you, whether it's from a candle, incense, or cigarettes. So, it's best to use them carefully and not too much!

title: Why do so many fast food drive thrus have 2 windows, but always have you pull to the second window?
text: Okay, so imagine you're at a fast food place and you want to get a yummy burger and fries. The drive-thru has two windows to help make things quicker and smoother. The first window is where you tell the person what you want and pay for it. They take your money and get your order ready. Then, instead of making you wait at that first window for a long time, they have a second window where they give you your food. This way, while you're waiting at the first window, the workers can start preparing your food. So when you get to the second window, your food is ready, and you can zoom away and eat your meal faster! It helps everyone get their food quicker and keeps the line moving!

title: What is Phagocytosis?
text: Phagocytosis is like when a tiny cell in your body, called a "white blood cell," plays a game of catch with germs or bad stuff that makes you sick. Imagine the white blood cell is a big, friendly monster, and the germs are little, sneaky monsters trying to mess things up. When the big monster sees the little ones, it opens its mouth wide and gobbles them up! After that, it breaks them down so they can't hurt you anymore. So, phagocytosis is just that cool way your body eats up the bad guys to keep you healthy!

title: Why do the almonds in Hershey's w/ Almonds, taste unlike any other almonds?
text: The almonds in Hershey's with Almonds taste different because they are covered in chocolate and mixed with other yummy ingredients. When you eat an almond by itself, it has a nutty flavor, but when it's inside the chocolate bar, the sweet chocolate and the crunchy almond work together to make a new taste! It's like when you mix peanut butter and jelly; they taste good together, but separately, they taste different. So, the special taste comes from the chocolate and how it blends with the almond!

title: considering all factors, is there a more environmentally safe alternative to pipelines?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big toy train that moves your toy cars from one place to another. The train tracks are like pipelines that carry things like oil or gas. Now, sometimes, these train tracks can cause problems for the plants and animals if they break or leak. A better choice might be using trucks or boats that can carry things without needing those big tracks. Trucks can go on roads, and boats can float on water, so they can be more careful and avoid hurting the environment. Also, we can think about using super cool things like electric wires to move energy instead of oil or gas, which is like using a magic carpet instead of the train! This way, we can keep our planet safe and happy.

title: How important is the moon to life as we know it?
text: The moon is really important for life on Earth, kind of like how a big nightlight helps you see in the dark. First, it helps keep our planet's tilt just right, which makes sure we have seasons—like summer and winter—that help plants grow and animals live happily. Second, the moon makes the ocean's waves go up and down, which helps sea creatures find food and stay healthy. Also, having the moon means our nights are not super dark, which helps some animals know when to sleep and when to be awake. So, without the moon, our world would be a little different and maybe not as good for living things!

title: Why are penny smasher machines at national parks, amusement parks, etc. allowed when when destroying or defacing currency is illegal?
text: Okay, so you know how when you put a penny in those machines, it squishes the penny and makes it into a cool shape or design? It's kind of like turning a regular penny into a fun souvenir! The reason these machines are allowed is because the pennies they use are already yours once you put them in the machine. So, you're not really destroying money in a bad way; you’re just changing it into something special. Plus, the law says it's okay to change coins for fun or art as long as you don't try to use them as real money afterward. So, it's all good fun and helps you remember your trip!

title: How do composers write music?
text: Composers are like storytellers, but instead of using words, they use sounds! First, they think about what kind of feeling or story they want to share, like happy, sad, or exciting. Then, they pick different instruments, like pianos, violins, or drums, to make their music. They might hum a tune or tap a beat to figure out what sounds good together. After that, they write down their ideas using special symbols called notes on a piece of paper, kind of like drawing a picture. Each note tells musicians what to play and when to play it. Finally, musicians practice the music, and when they play together, it sounds beautiful and tells the story the composer wanted to share!

title: Why would a president not choose cabinet members with longtime experience in that's cabinet's area of governance?
text: Sometimes a president might choose cabinet members who are not super experienced in a specific area because they want fresh ideas or new ways of thinking. Think of it like choosing a new team for a game: you might pick some players who haven’t played in that exact position before but can bring awesome skills from other games they have played. The president might believe that these new cabinet members can think outside the box and come up with better solutions to problems. Plus, sometimes it’s also about finding people who share the president's vision or beliefs, even if they don’t have a lot of experience in that specific job. It’s like picking friends for a project; you might choose someone you really trust or who has a great attitude, even if they haven't done that project before!

title: Why does water not catch fire?
text: Water doesn't catch fire because it is made up of tiny particles called molecules, and those molecules are made of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. When you try to burn something, like wood or paper, it needs to mix with oxygen in the air to catch fire. But water is already made of oxygen and hydrogen, and when they are together like that, they are very happy and stable. Instead of burning, water actually helps put out fires because it cools things down and takes away the heat. So, think of water as a superhero for putting out fires, not something that can catch fire itself!

title: How is it that the words "comb", "bomb", and "tomb" spelled similarly but all sound very different?
text: Great question! So, think of words like "comb," "bomb," and "tomb" as different toys that look kind of the same but make different sounds when you play with them. The letters in these words are like the shapes of the toys, and even though they have some letters that are the same, the way we say each word depends on how our mouth moves when we make the sounds. For "comb," we don’t say the 'b' at the end, so it sounds like "koam." For "bomb," we say the 'b' at the end, so it sounds like "bom." And for "tomb," we also don’t say the 'b,' so it sounds like "toom." Even though they look similar, our mouths have different jobs to do for each word, making them sound different!

title: My science teacher said, in physics 5x5=30 but in traditional mathematics 5x5=25. However in physics 5.0x5.0=25. why?
text: Okay, imagine you have a box of toys. If you have 5 boxes and each box has 5 toys, you can count all the toys and see that you have 25 toys in total, so 5 times 5 equals 25. That's regular math. Now, when your science teacher talks about physics, sometimes they use different ways to think about things involving measurements or the way things move. When they say 5x5=30, they might be talking about something special where they add a little extra to the answer, like if some toys magically appeared or something changed. But when we say 5.0 times 5.0, we are being very careful and exact about those toys, and we still get 25. So, in regular math, 5 times 5 is always 25, but in physics, sometimes they are looking at different ideas that can change the answer.

title: How possible is it to have a helicarrier (like the one from Marvel's Avengers) and how would it work or why wouldn't it?
text: Okay, imagine a big flying boat that can carry lots of people and things, just like in the movies with superheroes! A helicarrier is like that, but it's super high-tech and can fly really well. The idea sounds really cool, but making one is really hard. First, it needs to be super strong to hold all the weight of everything inside and still be able to fly. Right now, we have airplanes and helicopters, but making something as big as a helicarrier that can float in the sky for a long time is tricky because it needs special engines and lots of fuel. Plus, it would need a lot of space to land and take off, and not many places can handle that. So, while it's a fun idea from the movies, we don’t have the technology just yet to make it happen in real life!

title: What are the benefits of consuming alkaline (pH > 7) food and drink? Does it have any merit?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big balloon that needs to stay balanced to work well. Some foods and drinks can make this balloon more acidic (like sour lemonade), while others can make it more alkaline (like bananas or spinach). People think that eating more alkaline foods can help keep our balloon happy and healthy. Some benefits people talk about are that it might help with feeling less tired, having better energy, and even making our bones stronger. But the truth is, our body is really good at balancing itself out, just like a seesaw. So, while eating more fruits and vegetables is great for us and can make us feel good, it’s not magic. It's important to eat a variety of foods to keep our balloon in the best shape!

title: Why is the night sky more clear after it rains?
text: After it rains, the night sky looks clearer because the rain helps wash away tiny bits of dust, dirt, and other stuff that float in the air. When the air is cleaner, we can see the stars and the moon better because there’s less junk in the way. It’s like when you clean your glasses; everything looks sharper and brighter! So after a rain, the sky is like a big, clean window that lets us see all the pretty lights in space.

title: What does the EPA freeze actually affect?
text: The EPA freeze is like when a teacher tells the class they can't use any new toys or games until they figure out the rules. The EPA, which stands for Environmental Protection Agency, is a group that helps keep our air and water clean. When they freeze things, it means they stop making new rules or changes for a little while. This can affect things like how factories clean up their waste, how much pollution cars can make, or how safe our drinking water is. So, just like if the class can't get new toys, it means they might not have the best fun or learn new things right away.

title: How did ancient people know why were planets and what weren't?
text: A long time ago, people looked up at the night sky and saw lots of twinkling lights. Some of these lights moved around, while most of them just stayed in one place. The ones that moved were called "planets," which means "wanderers." Ancient people noticed that these moving lights followed certain paths in the sky, while the stars didn’t move like that. They used their eyes and wrote down what they saw over many nights, figuring out that the moving lights were planets. So, the planets were special because they danced around in the sky, while the stars just stayed put!

title: What about military training SO good at creating early risers?
text: Military training is really good at making people wake up early because it has a special routine! Imagine you have to wake up every day at the same time like a rooster that crows in the morning. In the military, they have a set schedule where everyone gets up at the same time, usually really early, so they can have enough time to do exercises, eat breakfast, and get ready for the day. They also teach people that waking up early helps you feel more organized and ready to face the day. Plus, if everyone wakes up early together, it helps them work as a team and feel strong! So, waking up early becomes a habit, like brushing your teeth every morning!

title: If musical scales of the same type (e.g. the major scales) sound the same but a different pitch, why are complex scales used over the simplest one?
text: Okay, imagine you have a box of crayons, and you really like to draw with just the red crayon because it looks nice. That’s like using a simple scale, like a major scale, which sounds happy and bright. But sometimes, when you want to make your drawing extra special, you might want to use not just the red crayon but also some other colors like blue, green, or yellow. Those extra colors are like the complex scales in music. They help make the music sound richer and more interesting, just like how your drawing looks better with more colors. So, even though the simple scale sounds nice, using complex scales gives musicians more ways to express feelings and tell stories with their music!

title: How does a hacker get caught? Couldn't they just go buy a $200 laptop, install their hacking tools from a cd or thumb drive, and then take it to a public wifi place (library, Starbucks, etc)? Then burn their stolen hacking data to a CD when they get home?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing a game where you try to sneak cookies from the cookie jar without getting caught. Now, if you wear a disguise and go to different places, it might seem like you can get away with it. But there are lots of grown-ups (like detectives) who are really good at figuring out who took the cookies. Hackers, like sneaky cookie thieves, try to break into computers to steal things. But even if they use a new laptop and public Wi-Fi, there are special tools and smart people who can look for clues, like footprints in the sand. These clues can show where the hacker went, what they did, and even who they are! Plus, when they use the internet, they leave behind a trail, like breadcrumbs, that can help the detectives find them. So, even if they think they're being sneaky, there are many ways to catch them!

title: Why do we feel strong emotions in our chest?
text: When we feel strong emotions, like happiness, sadness, or even being scared, our bodies react in special ways. It's like when you have a balloon and you blow air into it; the balloon gets bigger and tighter. In our bodies, when we feel something really big, our heart starts to beat faster or we might feel a tightness in our chest. This happens because our brain sends signals to our body to react, like getting ready to run or celebrate. So, when you feel something strong in your chest, it's just your body getting excited or nervous about what you're feeling, kind of like how a balloon gets bigger when you blow air into it!

title: Why is there little to no atheist representation in US congress?
text: Okay, imagine that Congress is like a big group of people who help make rules for everyone in the country, kind of like how teachers make rules for kids at school. Most of the people in Congress believe in a higher power or God, which is like having a favorite superhero that helps them feel strong and brave. But there are some people who don’t believe in any superheroes at all; we call them atheists. In the U.S., it’s a little bit like how most kids might like chocolate ice cream, so there aren’t as many kids who pick strawberry. Since many people in the country believe in God, they might not think about picking someone who doesn’t believe in anything like that for Congress. Also, sometimes people are worried about choosing someone who thinks differently from them, so they might pick someone who believes the same things they do. So, it's a bit like a game where everyone is trying to pick the same team, and the team with the superhero fans is just bigger right now!

title: How do broken bones fuse together?
text: When you break a bone, it’s like snapping a stick in half. Your body is super smart and wants to fix it! First, your body sends special helpers called cells to the broken part. These helpers work really hard to clean up any mess and make a soft bridge between the broken pieces. This bridge is like a cozy blanket that helps the bones stay close together. Then, over time, your body starts to make new bone material, which is like building a tiny wall on top of that bridge to make it strong again. After a while, the soft bridge turns into hard bone, and your bone is all better! It takes some time, like when you wait for a flower to grow, but soon you can run and play just like before!

title: How are dictionaries compiled? How do words get picked to be in a dictionary? How do they not 'forget' to put in a word?
text: Okay, imagine a big team of word detectives who love to find new words and keep track of them. These detectives listen to people talk, read books, watch movies, and look at what people are writing on the internet. Whenever they hear a new word or see a word used in a new way, they write it down in a special notebook. Then, they check how many people are using that word and how often. If lots of people are using it, the word gets a special gold star, which means it’s important enough to go into the dictionary!
