It helps keep you entertained and makes the time go by faster while you're running or cycling. Plus, sunlight coming in through the windows can make you feel happier and more energetic!

title: Why is it entirely possible to fall asleep while listening to music, but very difficult to fall asleep while listening to someone snore?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a big, cozy room where you can relax and fall asleep. When you listen to nice music, it's like having a soft, warm blanket that helps you feel calm and happy, making it easier to drift off to sleep. But when someone snores, it’s like having a loud, buzzing bee in the room that keeps making annoying noises. This buzzing makes it hard for your brain to relax because it keeps saying, “Hey! Pay attention to that noise!” So, the music helps you feel nice and sleepy, while the snoring is kind of like a pesky alarm that keeps waking you up!

title: At what point would it be too far along to worry about climate change?
text: Climate change is like a big problem we all need to help fix! Imagine if your favorite toy started to break because you didn't take care of it. The longer you wait to fix it, the worse it gets, right? So, there isn't really a point where we should stop worrying about climate change; we should always care about it, just like we care about our toys. Even if it feels like things are really bad, we can still help make them better. It's super important for us to take care of our planet every day, so it stays a nice place to live for all the plants, animals, and people!

title: Why do lakes freeze but rivers don't, in the same temperature?
text: Lakes can freeze because they are big and still, which means the water can get really cold and stay cold long enough for ice to form on top. Imagine when you leave a glass of water outside in the winter; if it stays still, it can freeze. Rivers, on the other hand, are always moving. The water flows, so it mixes around and doesn’t stay cold enough for long enough to freeze. It's like if you kept stirring your hot chocolate; it never gets a chance to cool down and turn into chocolate ice! So, even if it’s the same temperature outside, the still water in a lake can freeze while the flowing water in a river usually doesn't.

title: Where does the mustard from "mustard gas" come from?
text: Mustard gas gets its name from the yellowish color and the way it looks like mustard, the kind you put on hot dogs! But it doesn’t come from real mustard or any food. Instead, it’s made in a lab using special chemicals. People created it a long time ago to use in wars because it can hurt people really badly. So, even though it has "mustard" in its name, it's not something you would ever want to eat!

title: How does a tax on imports work? How does this tax shake down to consumers?
text: Okay, imagine you have a lemonade stand, and you sell lemonade for $1. Now, let’s say your friend from another town also sells lemonade, but he brings his lemonade from far away and sells it for $0.80. If lots of people buy his lemonade, you might not sell many cups. So, the people in charge decide to put a tax on your friend's lemonade when it comes to your town, making it cost $1.20 instead of $0.80. This way, your lemonade is cheaper and people might buy yours instead! Now, that tax is like a little extra money that goes to the people in charge. When the tax is added, it makes the imported lemonade more expensive for everyone, so they might choose to buy yours instead. So, in the end, you get to sell more lemonade, but the people buying lemonade have to pay a bit more if they want your friend's lemonade.

title: Why is America pro spending billions on a wall but against spending billions on universal health care?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of toys, and some kids want to build a tall wall around it to keep other kids from taking their toys. They think this wall will make them feel safe and protect their toys, so they’re okay with spending a lot of their allowance on it. Now, other kids think that instead of a wall, everyone should just share their toys and help each other have fun, which means they would spend their allowance to help everyone get toys to play with. Some kids don't want to spend money on sharing because they think it might take away from their own toys or they believe everyone should just get their own toys. So, it’s like some people think the wall is super important to keep their stuff safe, while others think helping everyone have toys is more important, and that’s why they argue about where to spend the money.

title: How are all-you-can-eat buffets profitable?
text: All-you-can-eat buffets make money by serving a lot of food to many people at once, but they are really smart about it! They offer a big variety of foods, but often they know that people won’t eat too much of everything. Many people fill their plates with a little bit of everything but don’t finish it all. Also, some foods are cheaper to make, like salads and bread, so they serve more of those. Plus, they have a lot of customers coming in, so even if a few people eat a lot, the restaurant still makes enough money from everyone else. It’s like when you have a big box of crayons, and you only use a few of your favorites, but you still get to color lots of pictures!

title: Cross-pollination by hand. To be more blunt, how can you make sure two plants have "sex"?
text: Okay! So, plants can have "sex" to make new seeds, just like how animals do! But they don’t have legs or arms, so they need a little help. Sometimes, bees and wind help them by moving pollen from one flower to another, which is like sharing a special dust that helps them make babies. If you want to help plants have "sex" by hand, you can use a little brush or even a cotton swab. First, you take some of that special dust (called pollen) from one flower and then gently rub it onto the flower of another plant. It’s like giving the flowers a friendly nudge so they can work together to make seeds. Just remember to be gentle so you don’t hurt the flowers!

title: Why do people from the US say that they are the most free in the world, even compared to first world European countries?
text: People from the US often say they are the most free because they have a lot of rights and choices. In the US, people can say what they want, believe what they want, and choose their own jobs and where to live. This is called "freedom." They feel like they can make their own decisions without too many rules holding them back. While many European countries also have freedoms and rights, some people in the US think their laws and way of life give them even more freedom. It's kind of like how some kids think their favorite toy is the best, even if other kids have cool toys too. Everyone has their own opinion on what freedom looks like!

title: How can humans die of electrocution from wires yet survive lightning bolts?
text: Okay, imagine electricity is like a super-fast river of tiny invisible things called electrons. When you touch a wire that's carrying this electricity, it’s like jumping into a really strong part of the river. The electricity goes through your body and can hurt you a lot, like getting a really big shock. But when lightning strikes, it's like a giant wave from that river that comes down all at once. Lightning is super powerful, but it usually wants to go to the ground, so if you get hit by it, it can go around your body instead of through it. Some people can survive getting hit by lightning because the electricity doesn't stay in them for long. But if you touch a wire, the electricity can stay inside you longer, which is why it can hurt you more. So, it’s all about where the electricity goes and how strong it is!

title: How does an import tariff on items from Mexico make Mexico pay for the wall?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big toy box and you want to buy toys from your friend in Mexico. If you have to pay extra money (that’s the import tariff) when you buy those toys, it makes them more expensive for you. Now, if you buy fewer toys because they cost too much, your friend in Mexico might not sell as many. The idea is that the extra money you pay goes to your own country, and then they can use some of that money to help pay for a wall or something else they want to build. So, even though Mexico isn’t giving money directly, the extra costs on the toys mean you’re helping pay for something your country wants!

title: What Caused the Great Depression?
text: The Great Depression was like a really big sad time for the whole world where many people lost their jobs and didn’t have enough money. It started in 1929 when a lot of people tried to sell their stocks (which are like tiny pieces of companies) all at once because they were scared the companies wouldn’t do well. This made the stock prices drop super low, like a balloon losing air. When people lost money, they stopped buying things, and then stores and factories had to close or lay off workers. It was like a big chain reaction where everyone got sadder and poorer. Plus, some other things like farms not making enough food and banks running out of money made it even worse. It took a long time for everyone to feel happy and safe again.

title: What does stretching do?
text: Stretching is like giving your muscles a little hug to make them feel better! When you stretch, you help your muscles get longer and feel more relaxed, kind of like how a rubber band can stretch and then bounce back. This makes it easier for you to move around and play without feeling stiff or tight. It also helps keep your body feeling good and can make you less likely to get hurt when you run, jump, or play games. So, stretching is like warming up your muscles so they’re happy and ready to have fun!

title: How does chat applications knows when the other person is typing before sending the message?
text: Okay, imagine you're playing with your friend and you can see that they are drawing something on a piece of paper. You can't see what they are drawing, but you know they are doing something because you see their pencil moving. Chat applications work kind of like that! When you start typing a message, the app sends a little message to the other person's phone or computer that says, "Hey, my friend is typing!" This way, the other person knows you are working on a message, just like you know your friend is drawing. It happens really fast, so they don't see the words you're typing, just that you are busy typing!

title: Why is it common practice to bury our dead in the ground?
text: People usually bury their dead in the ground because it helps keep the body safe and lets us remember them in a special place. When someone passes away, we want to show respect and love for them, and burying them in the ground is like giving them a cozy, peaceful bed. It also helps stop the body from being in the way, and it makes it easier for family and friends to visit and remember the person. Sometimes, we put flowers or special things on their grave to show we still care. Burying is just one way that many people honor those who have died, kind of like saying goodbye in a gentle way.

title: Why do kernels of microwave popcorn pop individually rather than in groups?
text: Okay, so imagine each little kernel of popcorn is like a tiny pressure cooker! Inside each kernel, there's some water and soft stuff called starch. When you put the popcorn in the microwave, it gets really hot, and the water turns into steam. This steam builds up pressure inside the kernel until it can't hold it anymore, and then—POP! The kernel explodes and turns inside out. Each kernel is separate from the others, so they heat up and pop at different times, just like if you were blowing up balloons, some might pop before others. That's why you hear lots of pops happening one after the other instead of all at once!

title: Why is the Midwest called the Midwest?
text: The Midwest is called the Midwest because, a long time ago, when people were making maps of the United States, they thought of it as being in the middle part of the west side of the country. Imagine if you have a big pizza, and you cut it into slices. The slice that is in the middle but still on the left side of the pizza is like the Midwest! So, even though it’s not exactly in the middle of the whole country, it’s kind of like the middle of the western part, and that’s why it got the name Midwest!

title: Why were the Repubs allowed to block Obama from appointing a new Justice-- for over a year?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big box of crayons, and you want to share them with your friends. But then, one of your friends, let's call him Mr. Republican, decides he doesn't want to share the crayons right now. When Mr. Obama, who was in charge of the crayons, wanted to pick a new crayon (which is kind of like picking a new Justice), Mr. Republican said, "No, let's wait until after the big party (which was the next election)." So, for more than a year, Mr. Republican and his friends decided to block Mr. Obama from picking a new crayon because they thought it was better to wait for the new leader after the party to make that choice. They believed it was fairer that way, even if it made Mr. Obama upset. This is how rules work in the big people’s game of government, where sometimes one side can stop the other side from doing something until a new leader comes along.

title: - What is actually happening when you get water stuck in your ear?
text: When you get water stuck in your ear, it means some water has gone inside a little tunnel called the ear canal, which is like a tiny tube that leads to your eardrum. This can happen when you swim, take a shower, or splash around. Sometimes the water just sits there because it can't get out easily, kind of like when you pour water in a cup and it doesn't spill over. This can make your ear feel funny, like it's full or blocked, and you might hear funny sounds or feel a bit of pressure. Your body usually helps get the water out by making you shake your head or by yawning, which can help the water find its way back out. If it doesn’t come out, it’s usually okay, and it should go away on its own, but if it stays too long, it can make your ear feel uncomfortable or even hurt, so you might need a grown-up to help.

title: What makes plastic surgery look so obviously overdone?
text: Plastic surgery can look overdone when the person changes their face or body too much, making it look different from how they really look. Imagine if you tried to make a funny face by stretching your cheeks really far or making your eyes super big—sometimes it just looks silly instead of pretty. When doctors do a lot of changes at once, like making lips really big or lifting the skin too much, it can look unnatural, like a doll or a cartoon. It’s important for people to remember that small changes can look nicer than big, drastic ones, just like how a little bit of frosting on a cake is yummy, but too much can make it too sweet!

title: How does imposing a 20% tax on Mexican imports, WHICH will be paid BY American Citizens, make Mexico pay for the wall?
text: Okay, imagine you want to build a big wall, and you think that people from Mexico should help pay for it. So, you decide to put a special charge, like a fee, on things that come from Mexico, like tacos or toys. This fee is called a tax, and it's 20%, which means if a taco costs $1, now it costs $1.20 because of the tax. When people in America buy those tacos or toys, they have to pay the extra money, which goes to the government. The idea is that the money collected from the tax can then be used to help pay for the wall. So, even though it’s American citizens paying the higher prices, the idea is that it’s a way to get money from things that come from Mexico to help pay for something in America.

title: why is cancer so fucking prevalent?
text: Cancer happens when some of our body's cells start to grow really fast and don't stop when they're supposed to. It's like if you had a plant in your room, and instead of growing nicely, it just kept getting bigger and bigger until it took over everything! There are a few reasons why cancer is so common now. First, people are living longer than before, and when we get older, the chances of our cells acting funny and becoming cancerous go up. Also, things like bad eating habits, not exercising, and being around certain chemicals can make it more likely to happen. So, it's a mix of living longer and not always taking care of our bodies that makes cancer more common these days.

title: Is it possible to be depressed without knowing it yourself? Without even suspecting it? If yes, how does that work exactly?
text: Yes, it is possible to be sad or depressed without even realizing it! Sometimes, our feelings can be like a big, heavy blanket covering us, and we might not notice it's there. This can happen if we're so busy with school, friends, or playing that we don’t pay attention to our feelings. A person might think they’re just tired or grumpy, but deep down, they might feel sad all the time or lose interest in things they used to love, like playing with toys or drawing. It’s like wearing sunglasses that make everything look dark, and you don’t notice it until someone helps you take them off and see the bright world again. Talking to someone, like a parent or a teacher, can help you understand your feelings better!

title: Why does the speed of sound increase again after a certain altitude?
text: Okay, imagine the air is like a big blanket made of tiny little balls called molecules. When you go up in the sky, like in an airplane, the air gets thinner, which means there are fewer of those little balls. At first, when you go higher, it gets colder and the balls move slower, so sound travels slower too. But then, after you go really high up, the temperature starts to get warmer again, and when it’s warm, the little balls move faster. Since sound travels by bouncing off those balls, if the balls are moving faster, sound can go faster too! So, the speed of sound increases again when it gets warm up high in the sky.

title: Why does school food tend to be awful?
text: School food can be awful because schools have to feed a lot of kids at once, so they need to make meals that are cheap and easy to prepare. This means they often use ingredients that aren't super tasty or fresh. Also, they try to make food that everyone will like, which can lead to boring choices like plain sandwiches or overcooked veggies. Sometimes, there are rules about what can be served, like making sure it's healthy, but that can make it harder to make the food yummy. So, while they want to feed you good stuff, they have to think about money, time, and what most kids will eat, which can mean the food isn't always the best!

title: If web browsers treat Javascript consistently, why can't they do the same with CSS?
text: Okay, imagine you have a box of crayons, and each crayon is a different color. You use these crayons to draw pictures on a piece of paper. Now, JavaScript is like the instructions telling you how to use those crayons, making sure you color inside the lines and do fun things like make your picture move. Most browsers understand these instructions in the same way, so they all color the same. But CSS is like the different kinds of paper you can draw on. Some paper might be shiny, some might be rough, and some might be different sizes. This means that when you try to use your crayons on different kinds of paper, sometimes the colors look a bit different or don’t work the same way. Each web browser has its own way of handling this "paper," so they might show your pictures differently, even though the crayons (JavaScript) are the same. That's why CSS can be tricky and not look the same everywhere!

title: What happens to our bodies to cause sleep walking?
text: Sleepwalking happens when a person gets up and walks around while they are still mostly asleep. It's like their body is awake, but their brain is still dreaming. Imagine if you were playing with your toys in your sleep without knowing it! This can happen because the part of the brain that controls our movements wakes up, but the part that makes us aware and conscious does not. So, the person can move and even do things, but they don’t really know what they are doing. It's more common in kids, and usually, they don't remember it the next morning. It's like a little adventure in their sleep!

title: Why do most Ameican homes in TV shows have fly screens, but they're uncommon elsewhwre?
text: Okay, so you know how sometimes you see bugs like flies and mosquitoes buzzing around? In a lot of American homes, especially in places where it's warm and there are lots of bugs, they put special screens on the windows and doors called fly screens. These screens have tiny holes that let air in but keep the bugs out, so you can enjoy fresh air without getting bitten! In other countries, they might have different ways to keep bugs out, like using air conditioning or having different kinds of windows, so they don't need fly screens as much. It's kind of like how some people like to wear hats in the sun to stay cool, and others like to sit in the shade. Both are good, just different ways to solve the same problem!

title: What does "/16 or /24" after an IP Address mean?
text: Okay, imagine your IP address is like the address of your house, and the numbers after the slash, like /16 or /24, are like how many people live in your neighborhood. When you see /16, it means a big neighborhood with lots of houses, like a big block where many people can live. But if you see /24, it’s a smaller neighborhood, with fewer houses and fewer people. So, the number tells us how many houses (or devices) can be in that neighborhood, helping computers know where to send information, just like mailmen know where to deliver letters!

title: Why are humans the only creature that needs help in giving birth?
text: Humans are a little different from other animals when it comes to having babies. Our heads are bigger because we have big brains, which helps us think and learn. But this makes it harder for babies to be born because their heads have to fit through a small space in their mom's body. Other animals often have smaller heads when they are born, making it easier for them. That's why humans usually need help, like from doctors or midwives, to make sure both the mom and baby are safe and healthy during birth. So while some animals can do it all on their own, humans sometimes need a little extra help!

title: why do a lot of businesses push me towards downloading their app?
text: Businesses want you to download their app because it makes it easier for them to talk to you and help you! When you have their app on your phone or tablet, you can quickly see what they have to offer, like special deals or new products. It’s like having a little shop in your pocket! Apps can also send you messages to remind you about sales or events, so you don’t miss out. Plus, when you use the app, they can learn what you like and make your experience better. It’s a win-win!

title: How big are human intestines and why?
text: Human intestines are really long! If you stretched them out, they would be about 20 to 25 feet long, which is like a big, twisty slide! They are long because their job is to help us digest food. When we eat, the food goes into our stomach and then into our intestines, where it gets broken down and turned into little pieces that our body can use for energy and to grow. The long shape gives the food lots of time to be mixed up and absorbed, kind of like how a long slide gives you more time to enjoy the ride!

title: How does a war neutrality work? For example, why didn't Germany just invade Switzerland and ignore its neutrality?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy box, and you and your friends are playing with your toys. Now, let's say your friend Timmy decides to start a big toy fight with other kids, but you don't want to play that game. You want to just keep playing with your toys and not get involved, so you tell everyone you're neutral, which means you won't pick sides. Switzerland is like that kid who wants to keep playing quietly in their corner, so they said, "I'm neutral!" Now, if Germany wanted to invade Switzerland, it would be like Timmy trying to get you to join his fight, but you really want to stay out of it. Sometimes, when a country is neutral, other countries respect that because they don't want to make more trouble or start fights with each other. Plus, Switzerland has lots of mountains and was really good at defending itself, so Germany might have thought, "Hmm, maybe it's not worth it to mess with them." So, neutrality is like saying, "I'm not fighting, please leave me alone," and lots of times, other countries listen.

title: How porn can "hurt everyone"?
text: Okay, imagine if you have a toy that you really like, but then you start playing with it too much. At first, it seems fun, but then you start forgetting to play with your other toys or even go outside to play. Porn is like that toy for some people. It can make them think about it all the time, and they might miss out on real-life fun and relationships with others. It can also make people have funny ideas about what love and friendship should be, which can lead to hurt feelings and confusion. So, when people get too caught up in it, it can end up being not so good for them or their friends. That's why some people say it can "hurt everyone."

title: Why are the Terms used in Anatomy and other Sciences usually derived from Latin or Greek?
text: Okay, imagine a long time ago, people in different countries wanted to talk about the same things in science, like the body or plants, but they spoke different languages. To make it easier, they decided to use Latin and Greek because many smart people back then spoke those languages. So, when scientists discovered new things, they picked words from Latin and Greek to name them. This way, no matter where you are in the world, if you know those special words, you can understand what everyone is talking about! It’s like having a secret code that helps everyone play the same game even if they speak different languages!

title: What limits our speed in space?
text: Okay, so imagine you’re riding your bike really fast down a straight road. In space, it’s kind of like that bike ride, but there are some special rules. The biggest rule is called the "speed limit," and it’s set by something called light. Light is super fast, like super-duper fast! Nothing can go faster than light, which is like the fastest thing in the universe. Also, when things go really, really fast, they get heavier and need more energy to keep going, like if you added weights to your bike. So, we can only go so fast because of that light-speed rule and because things get harder to move the faster we go. That's why space travel takes time, and we can’t just zoom around like in cartoons!

title: What is the white foam that forms on top of the water when you cook pasta ?
text: The white foam that forms on top of the water when you cook pasta is called starch. When pasta heats up in the boiling water, it releases a starchy substance, which is like tiny bits of glue that come off the pasta. This glue mixes with the water and makes bubbles, creating that foamy layer on top. It’s normal and doesn’t mean anything is wrong! Just make sure to watch it, so it doesn’t boil over and make a mess.

title: How do most companies monitor their employee's internet activity?
text: Most companies keep an eye on what their employees do online to make sure everyone is doing their jobs and staying safe. They do this using special tools that can see which websites people visit and how much time they spend on them. It's kind of like how a teacher watches students in a classroom to make sure they're paying attention and not playing games instead. Sometimes, companies also have rules about what sites you can visit while at work, like not going to places that might be dangerous or not meant for work. This helps the company keep things running smoothly and protect everyone from bad stuff on the internet.

title: People when they get old seem to be shorter than when they were young with at least a few inches. Why??
text: When people get old, they sometimes get shorter because their bones change a little bit. Imagine your bones are like little building blocks that stack on top of each other to make you tall. As people get older, those blocks can get a bit squished down or some might even wear out a little. Also, the soft parts between the bones in your back can get thinner, so the bones can get closer together. It's like if you have a sponge that gets smaller when it dries out. So, when all these things happen, a person might end up being a bit shorter than they used to be when they were younger!

title: How do transportation apps like Moovit or Navigation in Google Maps know exactly when buses are arriving late, where exactly are they, at what time will they serve, etc?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy train set, and you want to know when the toy trains are coming around the track. The transportation apps like Moovit or Google Maps work kind of like that but with real buses and trains! They talk to the buses and trains using special computers that send messages. These messages tell the app where each bus or train is right now, like "I'm at the stop by the big tree!" They also know the schedule, which is like a clock that tells when the buses should be there. If a bus is late, it sends a message saying, "Uh-oh, I’m stuck in traffic!" So, the app can show you this information and help you know when your bus will arrive, just like you would wait for your toy train to come around the corner!

title: How come Digg died but Reddit thrived?
text: Okay, imagine you have two toy boxes. One box is called Digg and the other is called Reddit. In the beginning, both boxes had lots of cool toys (which are like fun stories and news articles). People loved playing with both boxes. But then, Digg started to change how it worked, making it harder for kids to find the toys they liked. Some kids got frustrated and decided to play with Reddit instead, where they could easily find awesome toys and share their own. Reddit let everyone join in and share their toys, making it super fun for everyone. So, over time, more and more kids played with Reddit and stopped playing with Digg, which is why Digg kind of disappeared while Reddit became really popular!

title: What atomic properties determine the transparency of a material?
text: Okay, imagine that everything is made of tiny building blocks called atoms. These atoms can be arranged in different ways, and how they are arranged helps decide if we can see through a material, like glass, or if it's not see-through, like a wall. When light hits a material, the atoms can either let the light pass through, bounce it around, or soak it up. If the atoms are arranged so that light can pass through easily, the material is clear, like a window. But if the atoms grab onto the light and don’t let it through, the material is opaque, like a brick wall. So, the way the atoms are set up and what they are made of helps us know if something is see-through or not!

title: What will happen to someone if they die in space? Will they keep orbiting? Will they decay?
text: If someone dies in space, their body would float around because there’s no air to hold them down like on Earth. They wouldn’t keep orbiting like a spaceship does, but instead, they would just drift along in space. Without air, there’s no oxygen for their body to rot like food does on Earth, but over a long time, the body would slowly break down because of things like space radiation. So, it wouldn’t be like a quick decay but a really slow one, and eventually, it would just become part of space dust!

title: why must I first dial 1 before calling this number?
text: When you want to call a phone number, sometimes you have to add a "1" at the beginning because it helps the phone know that you are calling someone who is far away, like in another city or state. Think of it like putting on your shoes before going outside—it's an extra step you need to take to make sure you get to where you want to go. The "1" tells the phone system, "Hey, this is a long-distance call!" so it can connect your call properly.

title: Why is Social Media so addictive?
text: Social media is like a big, colorful candy store where you can see fun pictures, watch silly videos, and talk to your friends all the time! It feels really good when you get likes or comments because it’s like getting a little treat, and your brain loves those treats! Plus, there's always something new to see, like a surprise gift that keeps popping up, which makes you want to keep looking. Sometimes, people spend a lot of time in the candy store because they don’t want to miss out on anything exciting, just like how you might want to stay at the playground to play longer. That's why social media can feel super hard to stop using, just like it can be tough to leave a fun place!

title: Why does local anaesthetic have adrenaline in it?
text: Okay, imagine you hurt your finger and the doctor wants to make it feel better without pain. They use something called local anaesthetic, which is like a magic potion that makes that part of your body sleepy so you don’t feel anything. But, to make it work even better, they sometimes put a tiny bit of something called adrenaline in it. Adrenaline is like a superhero that helps keep the magic potion in one spot longer, so it can do its job without spreading all over your body. It also helps your blood vessels get smaller, which means less bleeding while the doctor is fixing your finger. So, the adrenaline helps the anaesthetic work better and keeps you safe while you get better!

title: Teeth grinding at night and how it can be so loud. Also how can our jaws clench that hard unconsciously but not awake?
text: Okay, so imagine your teeth are like little soldiers standing in a row. Sometimes when we sleep, our brains can get a bit confused, like when you're dreaming about dinosaurs and you accidentally kick your blanket. When you grind your teeth at night, it's like those soldiers are marching around and bumping into each other, making a loud noise! This can happen because your body is feeling a little worried or stressed, even if you don't know it, just like how you can feel scared in a dream. Your jaw muscles, which help you chew food when you're awake, are super strong and they don’t know they’re supposed to relax while you're sleeping. So they squeeze tightly, making that grinding noise, but because you're asleep, you don’t notice it. It’s like your body is playing a game while your mind is off dreaming!

title: What is the difference between serotonin and dopamine?
text: Okay! So, imagine your brain is like a big party with lots of friends. Serotonin and dopamine are two special friends at this party. Serotonin is like the friend who helps everyone feel calm and happy, kind of like when you cuddle with your favorite teddy bear or eat yummy ice cream. It makes you feel peaceful and helps you sleep well. Now, dopamine is the friend who gets everyone excited and makes them want to do fun things, like playing games or riding a bike. When you do something really fun, like winning a prize, dopamine jumps up and down with joy! So, in short, serotonin helps you feel good and relaxed, while dopamine gets you excited and happy about doing things!

title: What is the benefit to a company to enact a policy that prohibits promotion of employees from within?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons, and you want to share them with your friends. If you only let your friends who are already sitting at the table have more crayons, it might seem fair to them, but you might miss out on some really cool new friends who could bring great colors to your crayon box! When a company says they won’t promote people from within, they are trying to make sure they get fresh ideas and new ways of thinking from outside the company. This can help the company grow and be better, just like adding new crayons can make your coloring more fun and exciting! But it can also mean that some people who work hard and know a lot about the company might feel sad because they can’t move up. So, it’s a bit of a tricky choice!

title: What would happen if we detonated an atomic bomb in the eye of a hurricane?
text: If we detonated an atomic bomb in the eye of a hurricane, it would create a really big explosion and a lot of heat. The eye of a hurricane is the calm part in the middle where there's no wind, but around it, there are super strong winds and rain. The explosion would push a lot of air and water up into the sky, and it might change the hurricane a bit, but it wouldn't stop it. Hurricanes are really powerful, and they would keep going. Plus, making a big explosion like that could be very dangerous for people and animals, and it could hurt the environment too. So, it's not a good idea at all!

title: Why do we need discipline?
text: Discipline is like being a superhero for your own life! It helps you make good choices and do things you need to do, even when you don’t feel like it. Imagine if you want to build a big tower with blocks. If you just play around and don’t follow the rules, your tower might fall down. But if you take your time, put the blocks together carefully, and clean up after, your tower can be super tall and strong! Discipline helps us stay focused, finish our homework, eat healthy food, and even learn new things. It’s like a magic tool that helps us reach our goals and be our best selves!

title: What is so special about the M1911 pistol that it is still in use today but not other semi-auto pistols of the WWI and WWII era?
text: The M1911 pistol is special because it was designed really well for its time, and it still works great even today! Imagine if you had a toy that was super fun to play with, and it didn’t break no matter how much you used it. The M1911 is strong, easy to hold, and has a big bullet that helps it shoot straight and far. Other old pistols from World War I and II were either too heavy, not as accurate, or just didn’t feel good to use. The M1911 has a cool design that people like, and many soldiers and police still choose it because it is reliable and gets the job done. So, it’s like having a favorite toy that you keep playing with even when you have new ones!

title: Scientists figured a way to transform hydrogen into metal. Why is this important?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a really special kind of gas called hydrogen. It’s like the air we breathe but different because it’s super light and can float away. Scientists have found a way to change this gas into something solid like a metal, which is super cool! This is important because metals can do a lot of amazing things, like conduct electricity, which means they can help power things like our toys or even big machines. If we can make metal from hydrogen, it might help us create new, better things, and maybe even make energy that doesn’t hurt our planet. So, it’s like turning something fluffy into something strong and useful!

title: If radiation exposure can cause cancer how does it cure it?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a bad guy in a story, like a monster, and this monster is making trouble in a town. The monster is like cancer cells, which are the bad cells in our body. Now, there’s a superhero called radiation that can help get rid of the monster. When doctors use radiation to treat cancer, they are aiming at the bad cells to make them go away, just like the superhero fights the monster. But here’s the tricky part: while the superhero is really good at getting rid of the monster, sometimes it can accidentally hurt some of the nice people in the town, which are the healthy cells in our body. So, doctors are very careful to use just the right amount of radiation to help defeat the bad cells without hurting too many of the good ones. That’s how radiation can help cure cancer, even though it can also be dangerous!

title: Why does a 16oz bottle soda cost $1.79 while a 32oz fountain soda costs $.99?
text: Okay, so imagine you have two different ways to get soda. The first one is a bottle of soda that is already made and packed up, like a toy that comes in a box. That 16oz bottle costs $1.79 because it takes time and money to make, fill, and package it, plus the store has to pay for the bottle and the label. Now, the 32oz fountain soda is like getting a soda from a big juice box where you can fill your own cup. It's cheaper at 99 cents because the store doesn't have to pay for a bottle or package, and they can make it quickly by just pouring it from the fountain. So, even though you're getting more soda in the fountain, it's easier and cheaper for the store to sell that way!

title: Why is it that Autism affects males more than females?
text: Okay, so imagine that our brains are like special toys that can work in different ways. When we talk about autism, it’s like some of these toys have a slightly different way of working. Now, scientists have noticed that more boys get these special toy brains than girls. One reason might be that boys and girls are a bit different on the inside, like how some toys are made for playing outside and some are for inside. Some people think that the way boys and girls grow up and the way their brains are built might make boys more likely to have these different toy brains. But it's a bit of a mystery, and scientists are still trying to learn more about it to understand why this happens!

title: Why does time go so slowly when we're little, yet as we age, time seems to get shorter?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big jar of jellybeans. When you're little, like 5 years old, every jellybean in that jar is a whole year of your life. So, if you eat one jellybean, it feels like a really long time because you've only had a few jellybeans before! Now, when you get older, like 30 years old, you have a lot more jellybeans in your jar because you’ve lived more years. So when you eat one jellybean now, it doesn’t feel as special or long because you have so many more years behind you. It’s like if you eat one jellybean out of a big pile; it just feels faster. So, when we’re little, time feels slow because every year is a bigger part of our lives, but as we get older, each year feels smaller compared to all the years we’ve already had!

title: How is the US not facing human rights violations for closing the Flint, Michigan case?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big bowl of soup that you share with your friends, but one day, you find out that some of the soup has dirt in it. That's kind of what happened in Flint, Michigan. The water there got really dirty, and it made people sick. When people tried to say, "Hey, this is not fair! We need clean water!" it took a long time for anyone to really listen and help. Now, some people think that because the problem of dirty water isn't fixed yet, it feels like the people in Flint are not being treated fairly, like their rights are not being respected. But the government believes they are taking steps to fix it, so they think they aren't breaking any rules about human rights. So, it’s a bit complicated, like when you want your soup to be clean again, but it takes time and effort to make it right.

title: What do Negative Ion bracelets actually do?
text: Negative ion bracelets are special bracelets that some people believe can help them feel better. They are made to release tiny things called negative ions, which are like tiny pieces of electricity that can float in the air. These little bits are thought to help make you feel happy and healthy, kind of like how a fresh breeze can feel nice. Some people say wearing these bracelets helps them have more energy or feel less tired, but there's not a lot of science to prove that they really work. It's a bit like believing in magic – some people feel better when they wear them, but we don't really know if it's because of the bracelet or if it's just in their head! So, it's important to remember that while they might make some people feel good, they aren't a magic cure for anything.

title: How could NAFTA be terminated by a single country?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends have a really cool toy-sharing club where you all agree to share toys nicely. That club is like NAFTA, which is an agreement between three countries: the United States, Canada, and Mexico, to trade things like toys (goods) and help each other out. Now, if one friend, let’s say the United States, decides they don’t want to be in the club anymore, they can just say, "I’m leaving!" But there are some rules. They have to give everyone else a heads-up, like saying, "I'm going to leave in six months." This gives everyone time to figure out what to do next. So, if one country wants to leave NAFTA, they can do it by following those rules and telling the others they’re done!

title: Why do you stop being hungry after many hours of not eating?
text: When you don't eat for a long time, your tummy gets empty, and it starts to make a noise that says, "Hey, I want food!" But after a while, your body knows it can't eat right now, so it starts to use the energy stored inside you, kind of like how a car uses gas from the tank. This energy helps you keep going and makes you feel less hungry. It’s like when you play with a toy until the batteries run out, and then you have to wait for new batteries before it works again. So, after some time without food, your body just gets used to it and doesn't feel as hungry anymore!

title: Is there anything that tastes salty but isn't salt?
text: Yes! There are lots of things that can taste salty but aren't actually salt. For example, foods like soy sauce, pickles, and olives taste salty because they have special ingredients in them, like vinegar or brine, that make your tongue feel like it’s tasting salt. Even some cheeses and certain snacks can taste salty because they have natural flavors that make them yummy. So, even if you don’t sprinkle salt on something, it can still taste salty!

title: How do teachers quickly tell which students are intelligent over ones who are not?
text: Teachers can often tell which students are smart by watching how they learn and solve problems. Smart students might ask lots of questions, find answers quickly, or come up with new ideas. They might also understand things faster than others and remember what they learned for a long time. But it's important to remember that everyone learns in their own way, and being smart doesn't just mean getting good grades; it also means being curious and trying hard! So, teachers look for these different signs to help them understand how each student is doing.

title: Why is Apple suing Qualcomm?
text: Apple is suing Qualcomm because they are having a big argument about money. You know how when you borrow a toy from a friend, sometimes you have to give them a snack or a toy back? Well, Qualcomm makes special parts that help iPhones work, and Apple has to pay Qualcomm for using those parts. Apple thinks that Qualcomm is asking for too much money, kind of like if a friend wanted a whole bag of snacks just for one little toy. So, Apple is saying, "Hey, that’s not fair!" and they want to figure it out in court, which is like a place where grown-ups go to solve their problems.

title: What specifically allows some people to hold their breath longer than others?
text: Some people can hold their breath longer than others because of a few things. First, their lungs might be bigger, which means they can take in more air. It's like having a bigger balloon that can hold more air! Second, some people practice holding their breath, like when they swim underwater a lot, so their bodies get better at it. Their muscles get used to using less oxygen, kind of like how you can run longer if you practice running. Lastly, some people have better control over their bodies and can relax more, which helps them hold their breath without feeling scared or panicky. So, it’s a mix of having bigger lungs, practicing, and staying calm!

title: How is it safe/ sanitary not to wash black cast iron cookwear between uses?
text: Okay! So, when you cook with black cast iron cookware, it gets a special kind of coating called seasoning. This is like a superhero shield that helps keep food from sticking and makes it easier to clean. When you cook, the heat and the oil help to keep this shield strong. If you wash it with soap and water, it can take away that shield and make it less safe to use next time. Instead, after you’re done cooking, you can just wipe it with a paper towel or rinse it with hot water to clean it. This way, the pan stays safe and ready for the next yummy meal! Plus, the little bits of food left behind can add flavor to the next dish you cook. Just like how a toy can get a little dusty but still be super fun to play with, your cast iron can stay safe and work well without a full wash every time!

title: Why can't huge companies like Google and YouTube beat ad blockers?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy box full of fun toys, but some of your friends come over and start hiding your toys so you can't see them anymore. Those friends are like ad blockers, and the toys are the ads that companies like Google and YouTube want to show you. The companies try to find ways to make their toys more fun and easier to see, but the friends are really good at hiding them! So, even though the companies are big and have lots of toys, the friends are really clever at making sure you don’t see the toys they don’t want you to. It’s a little game where both sides are trying to outsmart each other!

title: How does plastic thrown in the garbage, which is destined for a landfill, make its way to the ocean?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big box where you put all your toys when you're done playing. Now, if the box is too full or if someone accidentally knocks it over, some toys might fall out and roll away. That's kind of what happens with plastic in the garbage. When people throw away plastic stuff, it usually goes to a big place called a landfill, which is like a giant trash box. But sometimes, if it's really windy or if rainwater washes it away, pieces of plastic can escape from the landfill. Then, they can get carried by rivers or streams that flow into the ocean, kind of like how a toy might roll down a hill and end up in the grass. Once the plastic reaches the ocean, it can float around and cause problems for fish and other animals. So, it’s really important to try to throw away plastic properly and recycle it when we can, just like putting our toys back in the box!

title: Why do small injuries (like paper cuts) seem to hurt so much more than more serious injuries?
text: Okay, imagine your skin is like a big, soft balloon. When you get a small injury, like a paper cut, it makes a tiny hole in the balloon, and that hurts a lot because there are lots of tiny nerves there that tell your brain, "Ouch! That hurts!" Even though it’s small, those nerves are like super-sensitive alarm bells. Now, with bigger injuries, the skin might get hurt deeper, but sometimes the nerves are not as close to the surface, or the body gets so busy trying to fix the big hurt that you don’t notice it as much right away. So, even though a paper cut is tiny, it can feel like a big deal because it hurts really fast and really sharp!

title: Sometimes when I'm driving and I squint, the traffic and car lights turn into rays, why?
text: When you squint, you're making your eyes smaller, which can change how light comes in. Lights from cars and traffic are really bright, and when you squint, the light can get all mixed up and look like it's spreading out into little rays or lines, kind of like how a star looks in the sky! It's like when you look at the sun and it feels like it's shining out in different directions. So, squinting helps you see better in bright light, but it can also make those lights look like they're bursting out into rays!

title: How exactly do the different settings on dryers (i.e. "Permanent Press") affect clothes?
text: Okay, so imagine your clothes are like your friends, and the dryer is a big, cozy room where they go to get warm and dry. Different settings on the dryer are like different kinds of games you can play with your friends. The "Permanent Press" setting is like playing a gentle game where you don’t want anyone to get too hot or too wrinkly. This setting uses warm air but not too hot, and it also cools down a little at the end, so your clothes come out nice and smooth instead of all wrinkly. Other settings might be hotter or have different times, which can be better for things like towels that can handle more heat or clothes that need to dry faster. So, the different settings help take care of your clothes in the best way for each kind!

title: Could an identical twin get off on a technicality if we can't know that it wasn't their twin that committed a crime?
text: Okay, imagine you have two identical twins, like two peas in a pod. They look exactly the same, right? Now, if one twin did something wrong, like took a cookie without asking, and the other twin says, "Hey, it wasn't me, it was my brother!" it can be really tricky to know who actually did it because they look so alike. In a court, where people figure out if someone did something bad or not, if there isn't enough proof to say which twin did it, the innocent twin might be let go because we can't be sure they did anything wrong. This is called a "technicality," which means a little rule that helps someone because we just can’t be sure. So, yes, if no one can figure out which twin did the crime, the one who didn't do it might not get in trouble at all!

title: Who would build roads under a Communist ir Anarchist regime?
text: Okay, imagine if we lived in a big playground where everyone shares their toys instead of keeping them for themselves. In a Communist playground, adults would work together to build roads so everyone can play together and get to the swings or the slide easily. They would decide how to share the work and the tools, like shovels and trucks, so everyone helps out. In an Anarchist playground, there wouldn't be a boss telling everyone what to do, so kids might decide together how to build the roads by having fun and using their creativity. They might form little teams and work together because they want to make the playground better for all their friends. So, in both ways, it's about everyone working together, but in different ways!

title: How are NCAA players not being paid?
text: Okay! So, imagine you play on a really cool soccer team at school, and everyone loves to watch you play. The school makes money from selling tickets and snacks because people want to see you and your friends do great things on the field. Now, the school says that they can't give you money for playing, but they can give you a nice jersey to wear and let you be on TV. They believe that being part of the team is a reward in itself. So, even though you’re helping the school make money, you don’t get any of that money for yourself. That’s kind of how NCAA players work too. They help their schools get money and fame, but they don’t get paid like a regular job. Instead, they get things like scholarships to help pay for school.

title: Why do some wounds get just stitches or staples to heal while others get packed with sterile gauze?
text: Okay, imagine your skin is like a big, soft balloon. When you get a cut, it’s like someone poked a hole in that balloon. If the hole is small, like a tiny poke, the doctor can just put some stitches or staples to hold the edges together, kind of like using tape to fix a ripped piece of paper. But if the hole is big or if there’s a lot of dirt or yucky stuff inside, the doctor needs to pack it with sterile gauze, which is like a soft sponge, to help soak up any bad stuff and keep it clean while it heals. This way, the wound can get better without getting infected, just like how we want to keep our toys clean so they last longer!

title: If monitors only have 3 colored pixels: red, green, and blue, how do we see colors like yellow on our computers/phones?
text: Okay, imagine you have three magical paint pots: one with red paint, one with green paint, and one with blue paint. When you mix these colors together, you can make lots of other colors! So, when your computer or phone wants to show you yellow, it takes some red paint and some green paint and mixes them together. It doesn’t use any blue paint because blue doesn’t help make yellow. So, by shining the red and green light together really bright, your screen can show you the color yellow! That’s how even with just red, green, and blue, we can see all the beautiful colors on screens!

title: Why does your flesh appear to glow red when you hold a bright light against it?
text: When you hold a bright light against your skin, like a flashlight, it shines through the top layer of your skin and makes the red color of your blood show up more. Our skin is a little bit see-through, so the light gets to the blood, which is red, and this makes your skin look like it's glowing red. It’s kind of like how a red balloon looks brighter when you shine a light on it!

title: Why is this pigeon the most common bird of cities? What allows the pigeon to thrive in cities?
text: Pigeons are the most common birds in cities because they are really good at living where lots of people are. They can eat many different types of food, like crumbs from our snacks or seeds we throw on the ground. Pigeons also build their nests in safe places like ledges on buildings, which keeps them away from the rain and other animals that might want to hurt them. They are super fast at flying and can find their way around easily, which helps them find food and their friends. Plus, people often like to feed them, so they have plenty to eat. All these things make cities a perfect home for pigeons!

title: If sitting is so bad for us, how bad is the third of our lives we spend lying down (sleeping)?
text: Okay, so imagine your body is like a toy that needs to be charged to work well. When you sleep, it's like plugging the toy into the charger. It's super important because that's when your body gets to rest, heal, and get ready for the next day, just like how toys need recharge time to play again. Lying down and sleeping helps your brain think better, your muscles grow strong, and your body stay healthy. Even though sitting for a long time isn't great for us, sleeping is different because it helps our bodies do all the things they need to do. So, sleeping is really good for us, and we need it!

title: How does Gintama get away with having parts of so many other anime series in it?
text: Gintama is like a big, fun puzzle where the creators love to play with pieces from other anime and pop culture! Imagine if you had a box of toys, and sometimes you took your friends' toys to mix them into your games. Gintama does this, but with stories and characters from other shows. They make funny jokes and references to those other anime, which makes it special and entertaining for people who know them. It's like a big party where everyone can join in and have a good time, and that's why it gets away with it! Plus, it has its own story, so it’s not just copying; it’s adding a fun twist.

title: Why do the Flamingo exhibits at zoo's look very easy to escape from?
text: Flamingo exhibits at zoos might look easy to escape from because they often have shallow water and low fences, but there's a good reason for that! Flamingos are really good at standing and walking around, but they are not great at flying away from their homes. The fences are just tall enough to keep them safe, and the water helps them feel comfortable since they like to wade in it. Plus, the zoo staff takes care of them and makes sure they have everything they need, so they don't want to leave! It’s like having a cozy home where they get fed and can relax with their friends.

title: sometimes when I'm listening to music through headphones and I yawn, the pitch of the music shifts down a semitone or so for the duration of the yawn. Why does this happen?
text: When you yawn, your mouth opens wide, and your ears can change a little bit too! Inside your ears, there are tiny tubes that help balance the air pressure. When you yawn, these tubes can make a tiny adjustment, and that can change how you hear sounds. It’s like if you were to stretch a rubber band; sometimes it sounds different when you pull it! So, when you yawn, the music might sound a bit lower because of this little change in your ears. Don't worry, it goes back to normal right after!

title: Why is it blurry when we look straight into water but clear when you wear goggles?
text: When you look straight into water, it can look blurry because the water bends the light that comes from things under the water. Your eyes are used to seeing things in the air, not in the water, so the bending makes everything look fuzzy. But when you wear goggles, they help your eyes see clearly because the goggles are filled with air, like when you're looking at things outside of the water. This way, the light doesn't bend as much, and you can see everything nice and clear!

title: if cocaine and meth release dopamine, why do they feel good?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a big playground, and dopamine is like a fun slide that makes you feel really happy when you go down it. When you do something fun, like playing with your friends or eating yummy candy, your brain lets you go down the slide, and you feel good! Now, cocaine and meth are like super fast rides that push you down the slide really, really quickly, making you feel super happy all at once. That’s why people feel good when they use them. But the problem is, just like too much candy can make your tummy hurt, using these drugs can hurt your brain and make it hard for you to feel happy without them. So even though they feel good at first, they can be really bad for you in the long run!

title: How do institutions like the ACT and the SAT come up with their standards?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends want to decide who can be the best at a game, like throwing a ball. You all sit down and think about what makes someone really good at throwing. You might talk about how far they can throw, how straight they can throw, and how many times they can throw it without missing. Then, you come up with some rules and ways to measure these things, like using a tape measure to see how far the ball goes. That's kind of what the ACT and SAT do! They are tests that help schools see how good kids are at reading, math, and other important things. To create the tests, smart people think about what kids should know and be able to do by the time they finish high school. They look at other tests and ask teachers and experts what’s important. Then, they make questions and check to ensure they’re fair and can really tell how well kids are doing. So just like you and your friends made rules for your game, the ACT and SAT make rules to help schools understand how well students are learning!

title: Why are things wrapped in aluminium foil to keep them warm but never cool?
text: Things are wrapped in aluminum foil to keep them warm because the foil helps hold in the heat, like a warm blanket. When you wrap food in foil, it doesn't let the warm air escape, so the food stays hot for a longer time. But if you try to use foil to keep something cool, it doesn’t work the same way. This is because foil reflects heat, which means it can help keep things warm, but when it’s hot outside, the foil can trap the heat inside instead of keeping it cool. So, people usually use ice or special containers to keep things cool instead of foil!

title: Why does density decide what sinks and what floats?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big bowl of water and you have some different toys: a rubber duck and a rock. Density is like a special power that tells us how heavy something is for its size. If something is really heavy for how big it is, like the rock, it has high density. If something is light for its size, like the rubber duck, it has low density. When you put the rubber duck in the water, it floats because it’s not heavy enough for its size to push down through the water. But when you put the rock in, it sinks because it’s heavy for its size and pushes down through the water. So, if something is less dense than water, it floats, and if it’s more dense, it sinks!

title: Why does time asleep feel the exact same whether it's four or eight or ten hours?
text: Okay, imagine you’re playing with your toys, and sometimes you take a short nap and sometimes you sleep a long time. When you wake up, your brain feels a bit like a computer that just restarted. It doesn’t really remember if it was a short nap or a long sleep; it just knows it’s ready to play again! So, even if you sleep for four hours or ten hours, sometimes it feels the same because your body is just waking up from rest and getting ready to go! But if you slept longer, your body might actually feel a little more happy and ready because it got more time to recharge, kind of like charging your toy’s batteries!

title: What is the difference between an expat and an immigrant?
text: An expat and an immigrant are both people who move to a different country, but they do it for different reasons. An expat is someone who goes to live in another country for work or adventure, often planning to go back to their home country someday. Think of them like a bird that flies away for a little while but plans to come back to its nest. An immigrant, on the other hand, is someone who moves to another country and wants to stay there for a long time, maybe even forever. It's like a bird that finds a new home and decides to build a nest there instead. So, the main difference is that expats usually think they'll go back home one day, while immigrants often want to start a new life in their new country.

title: Why is it that with old Christmas tree lights if one bulb went out the entire strand stopped working but with new lights if one goes out the others stay on?
text: Okay, imagine you have a string of Christmas lights like a row of people holding hands. In the old lights, if one person lets go of the hand, everyone else has to let go too, and the whole line stops working. But in the new lights, they have a special trick! If one person lets go, the others can still hold hands and keep the fun going. This is because the new lights have a little helper inside that lets them stay connected even if one bulb is out. So, with the new lights, even if one goes out, the rest can still shine bright!

title: Is the sound we hear when we speak how we actually sound?
text: No, the sound we hear when we talk is not exactly how we sound to other people. When we speak, we hear our own voice through the air and also through the vibrations in our bones and tissues in our head. This makes our voice sound a little different to us than it does to others. So, when you hear a recording of your voice, it might sound funny or weird because it's only the sound that travels through the air, like how others hear you!

title: Why are some animals noses wet?
text: Some animals have wet noses because it helps them smell better! When their noses are wet, they can catch tiny smells in the air more easily. It's like when you lick your finger and then touch something; it picks up more stuff! A wet nose also helps keep them cool and keeps their skin healthy. So, having a wet nose is super helpful for animals like dogs and cats!

title: Why do every (most) games start with one having to "press a button" to get to the game menu?
text: Okay! So, when you play a game, the people who made it want to make sure everything is ready for you before you start playing. The "press a button" part is like saying, "Hey, are you ready to play?" It gives you a moment to get settled, like when you sit down in front of the TV and grab your controller. It also helps to make sure the game is all loaded up and working, kind of like how you let your toy car get ready before you zoom it around. So when you press that button, you're telling the game, "Yes, I'm ready! Let's go!"

title: How can the president issue an executive order like the Muslim Ban without it the other 2 branches approval?
text:
Okay, imagine the president is like a captain of a big ship called the government. The ship has three parts: the captain (the president), the crew (the executive branch), and the helpers (the legislative and judicial branches). Sometimes, when the captain needs to make a quick decision to steer the ship in a certain direction, he can do that by giving orders to the crew without asking the helpers first. These quick decisions are called executive orders. 

The captain has some special powers that let him make rules about how the ship runs, especially in emergencies or when he thinks it’s really important. The Muslim Ban was one of those quick decisions. But it's important to remember that the helpers can still check if the captain's orders follow the rules of the ship, and they can say "no" if they think the decision was not right. So, while the captain can make these orders, he doesn’t have complete freedom, and the helpers can step in if they need to.

title: Why does a temperature like 18 degrees Celsius feel so cold inside a house that I would start to shiver and need a blanket or sweater, but when it's 18 degrees Celsius outside, it's easily T-shirt and shorts weather and considered nice outside?
text: Great question! So, when you're inside a house at 18 degrees Celsius, it can feel colder because of a few reasons. First, houses are usually made of materials that can make it feel chilly, like metal and glass, and they don't have the sun warming them up like outside does. Also, when you're inside, there might not be any wind or sunshine to make you feel warmer, and you might be sitting still, which means your body isn't generating as much heat. But outside, the sun shines down and warms everything up, and you might be moving around, playing or walking, which makes you feel warmer too. So even though the temperature is the same, the way we feel it can be different depending on where we are!

title: How does call audio to the other side of the world take 0-5 seconds, when it would take sound about 18 hours to get their?
text: Okay, imagine you want to talk to your friend who lives really far away, like on the other side of the world. If you shouted really loud, your voice would take a super long time to reach them, like 18 hours, because sound needs to travel through the air. But when you use a phone, it doesn’t send your voice through the air like shouting. Instead, it turns your voice into tiny bits of information, like a secret code, and sends it super fast through wires or the internet. This is like sending a letter really quickly instead of walking it over. So even though you are far away, the phone can make it seem like you are talking face to face, and that’s why it takes just a tiny bit of time, like 0-5 seconds!

title: What would happen if I followed one of those "Shoot the target to win a new iPhone" pop-ups on a webpage to the very end?
text: If you follow one of those "Shoot the target to win a new iPhone" pop-ups, it’s like playing a game that tricks you. At first, it might seem fun, but when you try to join, it could ask you to do things that aren’t safe. You might have to give your name, email, or even your phone number, and that’s not good because it can let strangers know about you. Sometimes, it can even put bad stuff on your computer or phone, like a virus that makes it act funny or steals your information. So, it’s better to ignore those pop-ups and not play that game, because it’s usually just a trick and you won’t really win anything!

title: Why is it easier to dwell on upsetting moments rather than happy moments?
text: Sometimes our brains act like a sticky note that only sticks to sad things instead of happy ones. When something upsetting happens, like if you fall and scrape your knee, it can hurt a lot and make you feel bad, so your brain remembers that really well to help you avoid getting hurt again. Happy moments, like a fun day at the park, are nice too, but they don’t stick as much because your brain thinks, “That was fun, but I’m okay now.” So, we have to practice remembering the happy moments more, kind of like taking a picture in our mind to keep it safe!

title: Why are my taxes so high, even with a high withholding amount?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big jar where you keep all your allowance money. Every week, you put some of your allowance into that jar to save up for a toy. Now, your parents also take a little bit of your allowance every week to help pay for things like food, your house, and your school. That’s kind of like taxes! When you get your allowance, some of it is taken away to help pay for things that everyone uses. Even if you put a lot of money in the jar to save, if your parents decide they need more money for something important, they might still take more than you expected. So, if your taxes feel high, it could be because the people in charge need more money to pay for things we all use, like roads and parks. Your withholding is like saving up, but it’s still possible for them to take more than you thought.

title: In a democracy, what is supposed to stop hypothetical 90% majority from literally killing off minority 10%?
text: In a democracy, we have something called "rules" and "rights" to help protect everyone, even if they're in the smaller group. Imagine if your class had a rule that everyone gets a turn to play with the toy, no matter how many kids there are. So, even if 9 out of 10 kids wanted to take the toy away from the 1 kid, the rules say they can't do that because it's not fair. In a democracy, those rules are like the laws that say everyone has the right to be safe and treated kindly. We also have leaders and judges who help make sure those rules are followed, so nobody gets hurt just because they are different. This way, everyone gets a fair chance, and nobody gets left out or hurt, even if they are the smaller group.

title: When a pot of water boils, where does the air in the bubbles come from?
text: When a pot of water boils, the bubbles you see are not made of air; they are actually made of water vapor, which is like steam! When you heat the water, the tiny bits that make up the water (called molecules) get really excited and start moving around super fast. Some of these bits change from liquid water into a gas, which is what we call water vapor. So, when the water gets hot enough and starts to boil, those bubbles are just the water turning into gas, and they rise up and pop at the surface, making the boiling sound you hear!

title: Why is chickenpox worse as an adult?
text: Chickenpox is a sickness that makes you have itchy spots all over your body. When you're a kid, your body is really good at fighting off the sickness because it's still learning how to do that. As you grow up, your body gets bigger, but sometimes it doesn’t fight off chickenpox as well anymore. When adults get chickenpox, it can make them feel a lot sicker than kids do, and they might have more spots or feel more tired. It’s like when you try to lift a heavy toy—it's easier for kids because they are smaller and stronger for their size, but for grown-ups, it can feel a lot heavier! So, that's why chickenpox can be worse for adults.

title: Why do we vocalize our thought process by saying, "um"?
text: When we talk and we’re not sure what to say next, we sometimes say "um" to help us think. It’s like putting a little pause in our words. Imagine you’re trying to find a toy in a big box, and you say "um" while you look for it. It gives your brain time to figure out what to say next without leaving a quiet space where it feels awkward. So, saying "um" is like a little helper that keeps the conversation going while we gather our thoughts!

title: How do auroras in the night sky work? How do they form? Why do they occur? Why do they only show up near the poles?
text: Auroras are like colorful lights dancing in the night sky, kind of like how the Northern Lights look! They happen when tiny particles from the Sun, which are like little bits of energy, travel through space and reach our Earth. When these particles get close to Earth, they bump into the air up high in the sky, especially near the North and South Poles where the Earth’s magnetic field is stronger. This bumping makes the air glow in pretty colors like green, pink, and purple! It’s like when you rub a balloon on your hair and it makes static electricity; the air gets excited and lights up. They mostly happen near the poles because that’s where the Earth’s magnetic field is strongest, guiding those particles to those areas. So, auroras are nature's way of showing us a beautiful light show when the Sun's energy meets our Earth!

title: How do mobile companies like Verizon and Sprint decide on data charges? Does using more data really cost them more money?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big box of crayons, and every time you use a crayon, it gets a little shorter. Mobile companies like Verizon and Sprint have their own big boxes, but instead of crayons, they have lots and lots of little pieces of information called data. When you use your phone to watch videos or play games, you're using some of that data. Now, it doesn't really cost the companies a lot of money to give you more data because they have a lot of space and tools to help them share it with many people at once. But to decide how much to charge you, they think about how many people are using data, how many new tools and towers they need to build, and how much money they need to make to keep everything running smoothly. So, if everyone starts using lots of data all at once, they might raise the prices a bit to help pay for more tools and space, kind of like if all your friends wanted to color at the same time, you might need to get more crayons!

title: Why do the hand rails on escalators not go at the same speed of the escalator itself?
text: The handrails on escalators don’t go at the same speed as the steps because they are designed that way to keep you safe and help you hold on better. When you step on the escalator, the steps are moving, but sometimes you might not be standing perfectly still. If the handrail moved at the same speed as the steps, it could feel a little weird and might not match up perfectly with where you are standing. So, the handrail moves a bit slower, and this gives you time to hold on and stay balanced while the escalator is bringing you up or down. It’s like when you walk up a slide at the playground; if someone is pushing you from behind, you want to hold on tight so you don’t fall!

title: Why do birth certificates have the adoptive parents instead of the birth parents?
text: When a baby is adopted, it’s like finding a new family for that baby. The adoptive parents are the ones who will take care of the baby and love them like their own. So, the birth certificate, which is a special paper that shows who the baby is and who their parents are, changes to show the names of the adoptive parents instead of the birth parents.
