So, to keep both bears and people safe, it's against the law to feed them.

title: Why do some plants require more shade than others?
text: Some plants need more shade than others because they come from different places with different amounts of sunlight. Imagine if you lived in a sunny place like a desert, you'd want to drink lots of water and be in the shade to stay cool. But if you lived in a forest where the trees block the sun, you might be used to less light and can grow well there. So, plants that like shade have learned to grow in spots where there isn't much sunlight, while plants that love the sun need more light to grow big and strong. It's like how some people like to play outside in the sun, while others prefer to play in the cool shade!

title: Why does cheap alcohol give me a significantly worse hangover than good alcohol?
text: Okay, imagine you have two types of juice: one is really fancy and nice, and the other is super cheap and kind of yucky. When you drink the fancy juice, it’s smooth and makes you feel good. But the cheap juice has weird stuff in it that can make your tummy hurt and make you feel bad later. Cheap alcohol has more of those yucky things called "congeners," which are like extra bits that can make hangovers worse. So, when you drink a lot of cheap alcohol, those extra yucky bits can make you feel really sick the next day, while the good alcohol doesn’t have as many of those bad bits. That’s why you feel worse after drinking cheap stuff!

title: Why are the rules for elections for federal offices allowed to vary between different US states?
text: Okay, imagine you and your friends are playing a game, and each of you can make your own little rules for how to play, as long as everyone agrees to them. In the United States, each state is like a friend in that game. The big boss, called the federal government, says that all the states can have their own rules for elections, like how to vote or when to vote. This is because the U.S. is made up of many different states, and they each have their own ways of doing things. Some states might want to let people vote early, while others might have different ideas. So, just like in your game, as long as they follow the main rules from the big boss, they can make their own special rules!

title: Why do military paratroopers use round umbrella-like parachutes, and not the rectangular ones, like sport/recreational skydivers?
text: Okay, imagine you have two types of parachutes: one that looks like a big round umbrella and one that looks like a big rectangle. The round ones are used by military paratroopers because they are really good at coming down straight and landing in tight spots, like a little field or a battlefield, without being blown away by the wind. They also open up quickly, which is important when you need to get down fast! The rectangular parachutes that sport skydivers use are great for gliding and steering, which is fun when you're jumping from high up and want to fly around in the air a bit before landing. But for military paratroopers, they need to get down quickly and safely, and that’s why they stick with the round parachutes!

title: Why does alcohol damage a filter so much more than water and how?
text: Okay, imagine your body's like a big cleaning machine, and it has filters called kidneys that help clean your blood. Water is like a gentle rain that helps the machine work well and keeps everything nice and clean. But alcohol is like a messy, sticky goo that makes the machine work really hard. When you drink alcohol, it can hurt the filters because it makes them work overtime and can cause them to get tired and not clean as well. So, while water helps keep everything running smoothly, alcohol can make the filters dirty and not work like they should, which is why it can be bad for you!

title: Why does hot water make dish soap so intense and cold water make it all disappear?
text: Okay, imagine hot water is like a bunch of happy little dancers that are moving around really fast! When you mix dish soap with hot water, those dancers help the soap spread out and mix in really well, making it super bubbly and strong. Now, when you use cold water, it’s like the dancers are sitting down and being really slow. This makes the soap not mix well, so it kind of just hides away and doesn’t make many bubbles. So, hot water helps the soap be really powerful, and cold water makes it chill out and not work as well!

title: If influenza is always mutating, why does getting a flu shot help? Doesn't the shot only prevent attacks from a certain strain?
text: Great question! Think of the flu virus like a kid who likes to change their costume every Halloween. Each year, they might wear a different outfit, which makes it harder to recognize them. The flu shot is like giving you a special pair of glasses that helps you see who the kid is when they're in their costume. The shot teaches your body how to fight off the flu if it sees the costume it’s expecting. Even though the flu virus changes a little bit each year, the shot is made to help your body recognize some of the most common "costumes" or strains. So, while it doesn't stop every single flu, it helps protect you from the ones that are likely to show up, making it less likely you'll get really sick!

title: What does a "double mickey mouse" in the artery mean?
text: A "double Mickey Mouse" in the artery is a funny way to describe a special shape that doctors see when they look at pictures of our blood vessels. Imagine Mickey Mouse's head and ears; when doctors look at some pictures, they might see two of those shapes close together, like two Mickey Mouses! This can mean there’s a little problem or a unique way the blood is flowing, and doctors use this to help understand what’s happening inside our bodies. It's like when you see a shape in the clouds; it helps doctors decide how to help keep you healthy!

title: Why is it easier for snow to stay some places than others?
text: Snow is like a soft blanket that falls from the sky when it's really cold. It likes to stay in places where it’s really, really cold and where the ground is flat or has lots of trees. Places with trees can keep the snow from blowing away with the wind, kind of like how a big umbrella keeps you dry in the rain. Also, places that are sunny and warm, like on a hill or in a city where there are lots of cars, can melt the snow faster because the sun shines down and warms everything up. So, if it’s cold and there are lots of trees or a flat ground, the snow can stay longer, but if it's warm and sunny, the snow goes away quickly!

title: How come units of area are squared?
text: Okay, imagine you have a little square that is 1 unit long on each side, like a tiny box. If you want to know how much space is inside that box, you multiply the length by the width. Since both sides are 1 unit long, you do 1 times 1, which equals 1. So, the area of that square is 1 square unit. When we talk about area, we are thinking about how many of those little squares can fit inside a shape, so we say the unit is "squared" because we are using two sides (length and width) to figure out how much space there is. It's like counting the number of squares that can fill a bigger shape!

title: How are fetal genetic abnormalities determined through the testing of the mother’s blood?
text: Okay, imagine you have a special treasure chest, and inside that chest, there are colorful beads that represent different things about a baby that is still growing in its mommy's tummy. When doctors want to know if the baby is healthy or if it has any special surprises, like extra or missing beads, they can look inside the treasure chest by testing the mommy's blood. This blood has tiny bits of the baby's DNA, which is like the baby's instruction book that tells how the baby is made. The doctors can take a peek at this DNA to see if there are any differences or problems that might mean the baby has a genetic abnormality. It’s like using a magic mirror to check if everything is okay in the treasure chest without opening it!

title: What makes full-motion video "full"?
text: Full-motion video is called "full" because it shows moving pictures that look real and smooth, just like a movie or a cartoon. Imagine flipping through a picture book really fast; if you flip slowly, you only see still pictures, but if you flip fast enough, it looks like the pictures are moving! Full-motion video shows lots of pictures in a row really quickly, usually 30 times every second or more, so that our eyes see a complete, flowing story instead of just a bunch of still images. That's what makes it "full" – it has all the moving action we want to see!

title: Why is email free to use? How do they make up the costs to running servers, staffing etc...
text: Email is free to use because companies that provide email services make money in other ways! Imagine you have a big toy box, and you let all your friends use it for free. But, sometimes, you put some cool stickers on the toys, and you sell those stickers to people who want them. Similarly, email companies might show ads to people when they use email, or they sell special services to businesses that want extra features. This way, they earn money to pay for things like servers (which are like big computers that store all the emails), electricity, and people who help fix things when they break. So, even though we can use email for free, the companies have other ways to make money!

title: How are beakers and graduated cylinders not affected by chemical reactions?
text: Beakers and graduated cylinders are like special cups and measuring sticks used in science, and they are made from strong materials like glass or plastic. When we mix chemicals in them, the beakers and graduated cylinders don’t change or get “sick” because they are designed to hold the chemicals and stay safe. They don’t react with the stuff we put inside, kind of like how a plate doesn’t get dirty when you put food on it. So, even if the chemicals inside bubble or change colors, the beakers and graduated cylinders just stay the same and can be used again and again!

title: What prevents pain from coming back after pain killers wear off?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a big owie, like when you fall and scrape your knee. Painkillers are like magic band-aids that help make the pain go away for a little while. But when the band-aid comes off, the owie can still hurt unless you do something to make it better. To stop the pain from coming back after the magic wears off, doctors might help you heal your owie better by giving you other medicine or telling you to take care of it, like keeping it clean or resting it. So, to really feel better, you need to take care of the owie, not just cover it up!

title: why do soccer fields look bigger when watching games in Europe then watching games in the US, even though (I think) they’re the same size?
text: Soccer fields are actually pretty much the same size everywhere, but when you watch a game on TV, the way the camera is set up can make it look different. In Europe, they sometimes use cameras that are closer to the field, which can make the players and field look bigger and more exciting. In the US, they might use cameras that are further away, so everything looks smaller. It's kind of like how a toy looks bigger when you hold it up close to your eyes but looks smaller when you put it further away. So, it's not that the fields are different sizes, it’s just how we see them on TV!

title: In the chess games between Google's AlphaZero and Stockfish 8, why is each game different? Why isn't each game just the same every time
text: Each chess game is different because the players make different choices each time, just like how you might choose to play with different toys or make different drawings every day! In chess, there are so many possible moves that even if two players know the same starting positions, they can pick different moves and create new stories on the board. AlphaZero and Stockfish 8 are like two super smart robots that think really hard about what to do next, and they try to outsmart each other. Sometimes they might play safe and do similar things, but other times they might be brave and try something new and unexpected! That’s why every game can surprise us and be special in its own way!

title: What happens in the brain during different states of consciousness (sleep, coma, passed out, "unconscious" etc)?
text: Okay! So, think of your brain like a big, busy city with lots of lights and cars. When you are awake and alert, all the lights are on and the cars are zooming around, which means your brain is very active, thinking and doing things. When you go to sleep, some of the lights start to turn off, but some are still on, and your brain is still working, just in a different way. It’s like a quieter time in the city, where some people are cleaning up and organizing things while others are resting. Now, when someone is in a coma, it's like the city is mostly dark and very quiet; not much is happening, and the brain isn't working like it usually does. If someone passes out, it's like a sudden power outage in the city; everything goes dark really quickly, and the brain isn't able to do its job for a little while. When we say someone is "unconscious," it usually means the city is mostly shut down, and they can’t think or feel like they normally would. So, different states of consciousness are like different times in a city, with lots of activity when we're awake, and quieter times when we're asleep or not fully aware.

title: How did early humans survive in cold weather before the invention of clothes?
text: A long time ago, before people had clothes, early humans had to be really smart to stay warm in the cold. They lived in caves or built shelters out of sticks and animal skins to protect themselves from the chilly wind and snow. They also made big fires to keep warm and cook food. Early humans learned how to hunt animals, and they used the fur and feathers from those animals to cover themselves and stay cozy. They would huddle together to share body heat, like when you cuddle with your friends or family to feel warm. So, even without fancy clothes, they found ways to keep warm and stay safe in the cold!

title: What is the exact purpose of a hunger strike?
text: A hunger strike is when someone decides not to eat food to show that they are really upset about something, kind of like a big protest. Imagine if you really wanted a toy, but your parents wouldn’t let you have it. Instead of just asking them over and over, you might stop playing with your other toys to show how serious you are. People do hunger strikes to make others notice their problem and hopefully change things for the better, like helping people who are not being treated fairly. It’s a way of using their own bodies to say, “I really care about this and want you to listen!”

title: If graphene is so great, why isn't it be used in anything?
text: Graphene is like a super thin sheet made of carbon atoms that are arranged in a special way. It’s really strong, super light, and can conduct electricity really well, like a superhero material! But even though it's amazing, there are a few reasons we don't see it in many things yet. First, making graphene is really tricky and can be expensive, like trying to bake a cake with a super fancy recipe that takes a lot of time and special ingredients. Second, scientists are still figuring out the best ways to use it and how it can help us, like learning to ride a bike before we can race. So, while it’s super cool and has lots of potential, we’re still working on how to use it in everyday stuff!

title: How is it possible that when talking on the phone, person A can suddenly lose signal and not hear person B, but Person B can hear person A perfectly well?
text: Okay, imagine you’re playing a game of telephone with a friend, but instead of passing a message with your voice, you’re using invisible waves that travel through the air. When person A is talking on the phone, their voice turns into these waves and travels to person B. Sometimes, if person A moves too far away from the phone tower or goes into a place where the waves can’t go, like a big building or a tunnel, the waves get blocked or lost. This means person A can’t hear person B anymore because the waves aren’t reaching them. But, person B can still hear person A perfectly fine if the waves are getting through to them and they stay connected. It’s like if you’re in a big room and you can hear someone whispering, but the person whispering can’t hear you because they’re in a closet where there’s no sound coming out!

title: Why is there no measuring unit for darkness?
text: Okay, imagine you have a room that is really bright with the sun shining in, and then you close the curtains so it gets dark. Darkness is just the absence of light, like when you turn off a flashlight. We have special measuring units for light, like "lumens" or "watts," to say how bright something is, but darkness doesn’t have its own unit because it’s not something you can measure by itself. It’s like measuring how empty a box is; you usually say how full it is instead! So, we just think about darkness in relation to light: the more light there is, the less darkness there is, and that’s how we understand it!

title: How is an ultra-sound tech able to calculate the weight of an unborn baby?
text: Okay, so imagine you have a special magic camera called an ultrasound that can see inside a mommy’s belly. When the doctor uses this magic camera, it sends out sound waves that bounce off the baby and come back, kind of like how you can hear an echo when you shout in a big empty room. The ultrasound machine listens to those echoes and makes pictures of the baby. Now, the tech can also measure how big different parts of the baby are, like the head and the tummy. They use some smart math and special charts that show how big babies usually are at different times. So, by knowing how big the baby is from the pictures, they can guess how much the baby weighs! It’s like measuring your height and using a chart to see how much you might weigh!

title: Best angle of shots to minimize the splash damage when peeing into a toilet?
text: When you pee into a toilet, the best way to keep the splashes to a minimum is to aim for the water, but not too hard! If you aim for the surface of the water at a gentle angle, like you're throwing a soft ball instead of a hard one, it helps. You can also try to aim for the sides of the toilet bowl just above the water, which can help keep the splash down too. So think of it like trying to make a nice, gentle splash in a pool instead of a big wave!

title: How do we actually find out how old something is? Lets say the dinosaur skeleton or just a human body that we find in a glacier?
text: To find out how old something is, like a dinosaur skeleton or a human body in ice, scientists use special methods. For really old things, they use a technique called "radiocarbon dating." This works like a clock that starts ticking when the living thing dies. When plants and animals are alive, they take in a gas called carbon from the air. After they die, they stop taking it in, and the carbon slowly changes into something else over time. Scientists can measure how much of the original carbon is left to figure out how long it's been since the thing was alive. For super old things like dinosaurs, scientists use a different method called "uranium dating," which looks at rocks and minerals instead. They check how much of certain materials are left in the rocks around the bones. By doing this, they can tell how old the bones are! So, it’s like being a detective but for old things!

title: Why do older people have such problems with technology?
text: Older people often have problems with technology because they didn't grow up using it like younger kids do today. Imagine if you never learned how to ride a bike when you were little, and then one day someone handed you a bike and said, "Go ride it!" It would be confusing, right? That's kind of how older folks feel with things like smartphones and computers. The buttons and screens are new to them, and they might not understand how they work. Plus, technology changes really fast, so just when they learn one thing, there's something new to learn! It's not that they're not smart; it's just a bit tricky for them because they're used to doing things in a different way.

title: How do gorillas/chimps etc get so strong when the vast majority of the mass in their diet is fruit and vegetables?
text: Gorillas and chimpanzees are super strong because of their muscles and how their bodies use food! Even though they eat a lot of fruits and vegetables, those foods give them the vitamins and energy they need to grow big and strong. Their muscles are really good at using the food they eat to become powerful. Also, they are very active and do a lot of climbing, swinging, and playing, which helps their muscles grow even more. It's like when you eat healthy foods and run around a lot; you get strong too! Plus, their bodies are built differently than ours, so they can be really strong with the food they eat.

title: How do cords get tangled?
text: Cords get tangled because when you move them or store them, they can twist and turn in different directions. Imagine if you have a long piece of string and you start to play with it by moving it around a lot; it can easily twist into knots or loops. Sometimes, if you pull on one end, it can pull other parts with it, making it more tangled. It’s like when you play with your hair and it gets all messy; cords just do the same thing when they’re not kept neat and straight!

title: Why do bladeless fans have a large open space in the middle?
text: Bladeless fans have a big open space in the middle because that’s where the air comes out! Instead of using regular spinning blades like a typical fan, these fans use a special design that pulls air in from the bottom and pushes it out through the open part at the top. This makes the air flow nice and smooth, so it feels like a gentle breeze. The big space helps the fan move more air without any blades getting in the way, making it safer and quieter too!

title: how come putting water on your face makes it dryer?
text: When you put water on your face, it might feel nice and refreshing at first, but sometimes it can make your skin dry later. This happens because when the water evaporates, it takes some moisture away from your skin too. Imagine if you spill a little bit of juice on the table and then it dries up; it can leave the table feeling a bit sticky or dry. Your skin is a bit like that table! If you wash your face with water and then it dries, it can pull some of the good stuff that keeps your skin soft right out with it. That's why sometimes your face feels drier after washing it with just water!

title: How come having the sun visible in your peripheral vision doesn’t permanently damage your vision?
text: When you look at the sun directly, it can hurt your eyes and make it hard to see because it's super bright and can burn your eyes, kind of like how too much sun can burn your skin. But when you see the sun out of the corner of your eye, it's not as bright because you're not looking straight at it. Your eyes have a special way to protect themselves, like tiny shields, that helps them not get hurt when something really bright is in your peripheral vision. Plus, your brain knows that bright light can be bad, so it helps you look away or squint to protect your eyes. That's why you can see the sun a little without it causing damage!

title: In a zero gravity environment, would a 10kg, solid metal sphere be more difficult to throw than, say, a baseball? And would it accelerate less given the same force behind the throw?
text: Okay, imagine you have a bouncy ball and a big heavy metal ball, and you're in a place where there's no gravity, like space. When you throw both balls with the same amount of strength, the lighter bouncy ball will zoom away really fast because it’s not heavy. The big heavy metal ball is much harder to move because it weighs more, so it doesn’t go as fast when you throw it. So, yes, the metal ball is more difficult to throw and doesn't go as fast because it has more weight, even in a place without gravity!

title: Why does yawning limit our hearing so much?
text: Yawning makes us open our mouths wide and take a big breath, and when we do that, it can change how our ears work for a little bit. You see, inside your ears, there are tiny tubes that help balance the air pressure, so the sounds can come in clearly. When you yawn, those tubes can get a bit squeezed, almost like when you pinch a balloon. This can make it harder for sounds to get through, so everything might seem a little quieter or more muffled for a moment. It's like when you put your fingers in your ears; it’s just a little harder to hear. But don’t worry, after a short time, your hearing goes back to normal!

title: Why do we care about the national debt?
text: We care about the national debt because it’s like when you borrow money to buy something big, like a toy or a bike. If you borrow too much money and can’t pay it back, it can make things hard for you later. For a country, the national debt is the money they owe because they borrowed to pay for things like schools, roads, and hospitals. If the debt gets too big, the country might have trouble paying for important stuff, or they might have to take money from other things we need, like parks or helping people. So, it’s important to keep an eye on it, just like you would if you were borrowing money!

title: How does glass shatter when run under super hot water or in a dishwasher?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy made of glass, like a pretty cup. When you heat up the glass really fast, like if you put it under super hot water, the outside gets hot really quickly but the inside stays cooler for a little bit. It's kind of like if you were standing outside on a sunny day while wearing a warm jacket; your outside gets hot, but your inside is still cool. This makes the glass feel squeezed and can cause it to crack or shatter because the outside and inside are not the same temperature. In a dishwasher, sometimes the hot water can do the same thing, especially if the glass was already cold before you washed it. So, it’s important to let glass warm up slowly instead of pouring hot water on it super fast, or it might break!

title: Freshman here- why wouldn’t everybody apply to as many colleges as possible?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons, and you want to color a picture. If you take out all the crayons and try to color with every single one, it might get messy and confusing, right? Applying to a lot of colleges is kind of like that. It takes a lot of time and effort to fill out all the forms, write essays, and get letters of recommendation. Plus, some colleges have special rules or require things that can be tricky. Also, people might not apply to many colleges because they want to focus on just a few that feel like the best fit for them, kind of like picking your favorite crayons to make a really nice picture. So, while it might seem fun to have lots of options, sometimes it's easier and better to choose a few that you really like.

title: Why is plant protein less bioavalible than animal protein?
text: Okay, imagine you have a yummy cake and a bowl of salad. The cake is like animal protein, and it gives you energy and helps you grow really well because your body can use it easily. The salad is like plant protein, which is also good for you, but sometimes it has things in it that make it a little harder for your body to use all the good stuff. This means that when you eat salad, you might not get as much energy from it as you do from the cake. So, animal protein is easier for your body to use, while plant protein is still good but needs a bit more work to help you grow strong.

title: What's the deal with the clothing brand Supreme?
text: Supreme is a brand that makes clothes, especially t-shirts, hoodies, and hats. It started in New York City a long time ago, in 1994. What's special about Supreme is that they make really cool designs that a lot of people like, and they don’t make too many of them, which makes them feel special, like a rare toy! People often line up for a long time just to buy their stuff because it can sell out quickly. Some people really love collecting Supreme clothes and sometimes they can even sell them for a lot more money later, like trading cards! So, it’s like a fun game where wearing Supreme makes you feel trendy and part of a cool club.

title: How long does it take from the slaughtering a cow, to me being able to pick up the meat at my supermarket? Also, what exactly goes on during that time?
text: Okay! So, when a cow is slaughtered, it usually takes about a week or two before the meat is ready for you to buy at the supermarket. First, after the cow is slaughtered, the meat is hung up in a cool place so it can chill out and get really tasty. This part is called "aging," and it helps make the meat tender. Then, the meat is cut into different pieces, like steaks and ground beef. After that, it's packaged up nicely so it doesn't get messy. Finally, the meat is sent to the supermarket, where it sits in the fridge until you come to buy it! So, it’s like a little journey for the meat from the farm to your dinner plate!

title: How does your body produce blood?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a really cool factory. In this factory, there's a special room called the bone marrow, which is found inside some of your bones, like your legs and spine. This room is super important because it makes blood! The bone marrow takes tiny building blocks called cells and mixes them together to make different kinds of blood cells. Some of these cells are red, and they help carry oxygen, which is like the fresh air you breathe, to all the parts of your body. There are also white blood cells that help fight off germs and keep you healthy, like little superheroes! And then there are platelets, which are like tiny band-aids that help stop bleeding if you get a cut. So, your body is always working in that factory to make sure you have enough blood to stay strong and healthy!

title: Why does massages relieve body ache when it adds pressure to the already sore muscle or joint?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big balloon that's all tight and squished up. When you push on it, sometimes it feels weird, but if you squeeze it just right, it can make the balloon feel better and let air flow in. Muscles can be like that balloon. When they get sore, they can feel tight and uncomfortable. A massage is like giving that sore muscle a gentle squeeze. It helps to push out the bad stuff that's making it hurt and brings in good stuff like blood and oxygen, which help it feel better. So, even though it might feel a little funny at first, the massage helps the muscles relax and feel nice again!

title: Why is Eggnog not sold year round?
text: Eggnog is a special drink that many people like to have around Christmas and the holidays because it tastes like sweet and creamy happiness, kind of like a milkshake with a bit of spice! It’s made with eggs, milk, sugar, and sometimes a little bit of alcohol, which is like a grown-up drink. The reason we don’t see it all year long is that it’s mostly made for the festive season, and people enjoy it more when it's cold outside and they’re celebrating with family and friends. Plus, it needs fresh eggs and milk, and those ingredients don’t stay good forever, so making it all the time wouldn’t be easy! So, it’s kind of like a special treat that comes around just for the holidays!

title: How does half-life work in radioactive decay? Why does how much is left effect how fast the rest disappears?
text: Okay! Imagine you have a big jar of jelly beans, and every hour, half of the jelly beans disappear because they turn into a different candy. So, if you start with 10 jelly beans, after one hour, you will have 5 jelly beans left. After another hour, those 5 will turn into 2.5 jelly beans, but since you can’t have half a jelly bean, let’s say you just have 2 jelly beans left. After another hour, those 2 will turn into 1 jelly bean. You see, the more jelly beans you have, the more jelly beans disappear! This is kind of like how half-life works in radioactive decay. The “half-life” is just the time it takes for half of the stuff to go away. It doesn’t matter how much you started with; it always takes the same time for half of it to disappear. So, if you have less left, there’s less to disappear, but the time it takes to lose half stays the same!

title: How do creams that you put on your skin help muscles?
text: Okay, imagine your muscles are like little balloons inside your body that help you move and play. Sometimes, those balloons can feel tight or sore, kind of like if you squeezed them too hard. When you put cream on your skin, it's like giving your balloons a nice hug. The cream can have special ingredients that help make your muscles feel better by warming them up or cooling them down, kind of like how a warm blanket or a cool ice pack can help when you feel uncomfortable. So, when you rub the cream on, it goes into your skin and helps your muscles feel more relaxed and happy, so you can jump, run, and play without any ouchies!

title: How can the FCC force a vote?
text: Okay, so imagine you and your friends are trying to decide what game to play, but some of your friends aren't listening. The FCC is like the teacher in charge of making sure everyone plays fair with things like the internet. To make a vote happen, they can say, “Alright, everyone, we’re going to take a vote now!” They can do this by setting a special meeting where everyone has to be there, and then they ask everyone to raise their hands for what they want. This way, the FCC makes sure that everyone gets a chance to say what they think and make a decision together.

title: Why do some people have sparkling eyes (in contrast to "blank" inexpressive eyes)?
text: Some people have sparkling eyes because their eyes look bright and full of energy, like a shiny star! This can happen when they are happy, excited, or interested in something. It’s like when you see a toy you really want, your eyes might light up and sparkle! On the other hand, some people's eyes can look blank or inexpressive when they are feeling sad, tired, or not really thinking about anything special. It’s kind of like when a toy is turned off and doesn’t light up; it’s still a toy, but it doesn’t look as fun. So, sparkling eyes show feelings and excitement, while blank eyes can mean someone is not feeling much at that moment.

title: why do eyes roll back when people die? Or is that made up?
text: When people die, their body goes through some changes. One of those changes can make the muscles in the eyes relax, which can cause the eyes to roll back a little. It’s not something that happens to everyone, and it’s not something that people do on purpose. It’s just part of how the body stops working when someone passes away. So, it’s not made up, but it’s just one of the many things that can happen when someone dies.

title: Why are humans the only species that communicate using words? Are there other animals that have the capability to create/form words?
text: Humans are special because we have very smart brains that can think of lots of different ideas and put them into words. Words are like magic sounds that help us share our thoughts and feelings with each other. Other animals can talk, but not like us. For example, dogs bark and cats meow, and they can make sounds to show they are happy or scared. Some animals, like parrots, can even learn to repeat words we say! But they don’t make new words or sentences like we do. They don’t use language to share complex ideas or stories. So, while many animals can communicate in their own ways, humans are the only ones who have the superpower to use words to talk about anything we imagine!

title: How did we come up with the asteroid theory for dinosaur extinction?
text: A long time ago, scientists found a big mystery: why did dinosaurs disappear? They looked at clues like giant holes in the ground and tiny rocks called "iridium" that were found in a layer of dirt. Iridium is super rare on Earth but can be found in space rocks. So, some scientists thought, "What if a really big space rock, called an asteroid, crashed into Earth?" This crash would have made a huge explosion, like a giant firework, which could have darkened the sky with dust and made it hard for plants to grow. Without plants, the dinosaurs wouldn't have enough food to eat, and that could explain why they all went away. So, the asteroid theory is like a big puzzle that helps us understand what happened to the dinosaurs a long, long time ago!

title: How come you have that break in your voice that separates falsetto and normal voice?
text: Okay, imagine your voice is like a slide at the playground. When you go down the slide normally, that's like your regular voice, which is deep and strong. But sometimes, if you want to go down a different part of the slide that’s higher up and squeaky, that’s like your falsetto voice, which is really high and light. When you switch from the normal slide to the squeaky part, there’s a little bump or break, just like how your voice can suddenly change from low to high. This bump happens because your voice box, called the larynx, has to work differently to make those different sounds. So, that break is just where your voice is changing from strong to light, like moving from one slide to another!

title: Why did the 1892 Populist Party in the United States demand inflation through free and unlimited coinage of silver (what was its benefits)?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big jar of candies, and everyone wants to share them. Now, if you suddenly found a way to make more candies appear, every friend would get more candies, and they could buy more toys or snacks! The Populist Party in 1892 wanted to make more money by using silver, just like making more candies, because they thought it would help regular people buy more things they needed, like food and clothes. They believed that if there was more money around, it would be easier for families to pay their bills and not be so worried about being poor. So, the idea was that by making money from silver, people could have more chances to be happy and have what they needed!

title: And non-american by the way,how did New York City get so populated compared to other US cities and why does it stay so populated ?
text: Okay, imagine New York City is like a really big, exciting playground that lots of people want to visit and live in. A long time ago, many people from different countries came to America, and New York City was one of the first places they saw because it had a big statue called the Statue of Liberty that welcomed them. They thought, "Wow, this place looks cool!" So, they settled there. Over time, more and more people came because there were lots of jobs, schools, and fun things to do, like shows and parks. It stayed so populated because people kept moving there for better opportunities, and it has lots of interesting things that make people want to stay. Plus, it's a place where many families have lived for a long time, so they don't want to leave. So, New York City is like a super busy and fun place where everyone wants to be!

title: How can a film that grosses higher profits than the budget it took to make it still sometimes be considered a financial flop?
text: Okay, imagine you have a lemonade stand. You spend $5 to buy lemons and sugar, and then you sell your lemonade and make $10. Yay, you made a profit of $5! But then, let’s say your friend spends $1 to make a super fancy lemonade stand. They spend $100 on their stand and sell enough lemonade to make $200. They made a profit of $100! Even though your lemonade stand made money, your friend’s stand made a lot more. In movies, sometimes a film can make more money than it cost to make, but if it doesn’t make enough compared to what other movies made or what the studio hoped for, it can still be seen as a flop. It's like if your lemonade was good, but not as good as your friend's fancy lemonade - you both made money, but one was way better!

title: Why do things creak when you moved/touched it after not touching/moving it for a long time?
text: Things creak when you move or touch them after a long time because they might be a little stiff or stuck in one place. Imagine if you haven't moved your toy in a long time, and when you finally pick it up, it makes a noise because the pieces are moving again. This happens because things like wood or metal can change a little when they sit still for a while, like how your joints might crack when you stretch after sitting for too long. The creaking noise is just the material shifting and adjusting back to being used again!

title: Why can't some functions be integrated?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of different shapes, like circles, squares, and triangles, and you want to count how much space each shape takes up, or their "area." Most shapes are easy to measure, like a square or a circle, because we have simple rules to do that. But sometimes, there are very weird shapes that don't follow those simple rules, and we can't find their area using those same methods. In math, when we talk about functions, some of them are like those weird shapes. They can be so complicated or have crazy twists and turns that we can't find a simple answer for their "area" or how they behave when we try to integrate them, which is just a fancy way of saying we're trying to add up all the little bits of the function. So, some functions can't be integrated because they're just too tricky for our usual tools!

title: What does it mean to have something notarized?
text: Having something notarized means getting a special person called a notary to help make sure a paper is real and not a trick. Imagine you have a drawing you want to show your teacher, but you want to prove it’s really yours. A notary is like a grown-up helper who looks at your drawing, checks that you are really the one who made it, and then puts a special stamp or signature on it to say, “Yep, this is true!” This makes the paper more official, like a superhero badge, so other people believe it’s important and real.

title: why do milk alternatives [soy almond etc] get called milk and not *name* water?
text: Okay, so think about when you drink milk from a cow. It’s thick and creamy, right? Now, when people make things like almond milk or soy milk, they take the nuts or beans and mix them with water to make something that looks and feels kind of like cow's milk. They call it "milk" because it’s used in similar ways, like in cereal or in a glass, and it has a similar texture. If they called it "almond water" or "soy water," people might think it’s just plain water, which is different and not as tasty! So, calling it "milk" helps everyone understand that it’s a yummy drink you can use just like regular milk!

title: How does my penis know I’m looking at something sexual?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a really smart control center, and it helps your body know how to feel and react to different things. When you see something that your brain thinks is sexual or makes you feel excited, it sends little messages to your body. These messages travel through special pathways called nerves. So, if you see something that makes you feel happy or curious in a special way, your brain tells your penis to get ready, like when you get excited to play your favorite game! It’s just your body’s way of reacting to something that it thinks is important or interesting.

title: How does a pool table know to return the white ball when it's sunk, but keeps the coloured balls?
text: Okay, so imagine a pool table is like a magic box that knows what to do! When you play pool and hit the white ball (the cue ball) into a pocket, there's a special little door inside the table that opens up just for that ball. This door is like a secret slide that sends the white ball back to where you start playing again. But for the colored balls, the table doesn’t have that special door, so when they go into a pocket, they just stay there. They are like treasure that you keep! So, the table knows to send the white ball back to you because you always need it to keep playing, but it keeps the colored balls because you want to win by getting them all in the pockets!

title: How can we so distinctly remember things that never actually happened?
text: Sometimes our brains play tricks on us, like a magician! Imagine you have a big box of crayons, and sometimes you mix up the colors or think you saw a color that’s not really there. When we remember things that didn’t really happen, it’s like our brains are mixing up memories, just like mixing up crayons. This can happen because we hear stories, see pictures, or talk about things a lot, and our minds can start to believe those things are real. It’s like pretending or dreaming, and sometimes our brains can’t tell the difference between what really happened and what we imagined or heard.

title: How do deep space spacecraft such as Voyager orient themselves to point in a specific direction?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy spaceship and you want it to point at a certain star in the sky. Deep space spacecraft like Voyager do something similar, but they use special tools to help them know where they are and where to look. They have something called gyroscopes, which are like spinning tops that help them feel which way they're pointing. They also have cameras and sensors that can see stars and planets. By looking at these stars, the spacecraft can figure out its direction, like how you can tell which way is north by looking at the North Star. Then, it uses little rockets to move and turn until it’s pointing in the right way, just like you might turn your toy spaceship to aim it at a star. So, by using these tools and a bit of rocket power, Voyager can steer itself in the vastness of space!

title: Considering how inept the pinky finger is, why do humans actually need it?
text: The pinky finger might seem small and not very useful, but it actually helps our hands do a lot of important things! Imagine trying to hold a big cup of juice or a toy; your pinky finger helps keep your grip strong and steady so you don’t drop it. It also helps balance your hand when you’re using your other fingers to do stuff, like writing or picking things up. Even though it might feel a bit weak, the pinky is like a little helper that makes sure our hands can work well together!

title: How do Snowflakes get that cool pattern?
text: Snowflakes get their cool patterns because of how water turns into ice when it's really cold! When water in the air gets super chilly, it freezes and makes tiny ice crystals. These crystals start to grow and change shape as more water freezes onto them. The reason they have different patterns is because of the temperature and humidity in the air while they're growing. Just like how some kids like to draw stars and others like to draw hearts, each snowflake is special and unique! No two snowflakes are exactly the same, kind of like how each of us is different!

title: why does even a little bit of heat aggravate a (fresh) burn wound?
text: When you get a burn, your skin gets hurt, kind of like when you scrape your knee. The skin becomes very sensitive and feels ouchy because it's trying to heal. When you touch a fresh burn with something warm, like warm water or even just the air, it makes the hurt feelings even stronger. This is because the nerves in the burnt skin are all excited and can’t handle the extra heat, so they send more messages to your brain saying, "Ouch! This hurts!" It's like when you touch something hot and it makes you jump back quickly; your skin is super sensitive and doesn't like anything that feels hot, even just a little bit!

title: how does DNA trace ancestry?
text: DNA is like a special code that tells our bodies how to grow and what to look like, kind of like a recipe for baking a cake. When we want to find out where our families come from, scientists can look at this DNA code. Each person gets half of their DNA from their mom and half from their dad, so we all share parts of our DNA with our family. By looking at tiny parts of our DNA, scientists can see similarities with other people who are related to us, even if they lived a long time ago. They can also compare our DNA to the DNA of people from different places in the world to see where our ancestors might have come from, like if they lived in Africa, Europe, or Asia. It’s like a big family tree that helps us understand our roots!

title: Why can we HEAR our joints crack? How does sound escape the inside of our body?
text: When you move your joints, like when you bend your fingers or your knees, sometimes they make a popping or cracking sound. This happens because there are tiny bubbles in the liquid that helps your joints move smoothly. When you stretch or move your joint, those bubbles can pop, and that makes a sound! The sound escapes from inside your body because it travels through the air, and our ears are really good at picking up those noises. So, even though the sound starts inside your body, it can come out and we can hear it!

title: why does ESPN keep writing articles on what shoes NBA players wear?
text: ESPN writes articles about what shoes NBA players wear because a lot of fans love basketball and want to know everything about their favorite players, just like how kids might want to know what toys their friends have. Shoes are a big part of basketball because they help players run and jump better, and some shoes are super cool or look really nice. Plus, some players even make special shoes that fans can buy, so it's like a fun way for fans to feel closer to their heroes. It’s like talking about what superheroes wear, but instead, it’s about the shoes that help the players be amazing on the court!

title: Why are babies so flexible?
text: Babies are super flexible because their bones are still soft and squishy! Think of it like play dough; when you press on it, it bends and squishes easily. Babies have a lot of cartilage, which is a special kind of soft bone that helps them move their arms and legs around freely. As they grow up, their bones get harder and stronger, just like when play dough dries out and becomes harder. So, being flexible helps babies move and explore their world safely!

title: Why is plastic such a good insulator on windows in the winter?
text: Okay, imagine you have a really warm blanket that keeps you cozy when it's cold outside. Plastic is like that blanket for windows! When it's cold in winter, plastic can help keep the warm air inside your house and the cold air outside. This is because plastic doesn't let heat pass through it very easily, kind of like how your blanket stops the cold from touching you. So, when you put plastic on windows, it helps keep your home warm and makes it feel nice and toasty, just like being snuggled in a warm blanket!

title: Graphene, Graphite, and why one is an amazing super-material and the other is pencil lead and skateboard layers?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of LEGO bricks. Graphite is like a big stack of LEGO bricks all piled up together in layers, just like the way you might stack your toy blocks when you’re done playing. When you write with a pencil, the tip of the pencil breaks off some of those layers of graphite, and that’s what leaves a mark on your paper – it’s like the LEGO bricks coming off and leaving a trail. Now, graphene is like taking just one tiny, super-thin layer from that stack of LEGO bricks and making a cool new thing out of it. It’s super special because it’s really strong, super light, and can help make things like faster computers or better batteries. So, while graphite is used for writing and is just a bunch of layers, graphene is the amazing super-material that can do all sorts of awesome things!

title: How does an athlete using smelling salts work?
text: Okay, so imagine you're feeling really sleepy or a bit wobbly, like when you just woke up from a nap. Smelling salts are like a magic little potion in a bottle that has a strong smell, usually like ammonia, which is a bit like stinky vinegar. When an athlete sniffs the salts, the strong smell goes up their nose and makes them feel more awake and alert, kind of like when you eat something sour and it makes your face go "whoa!" This helps them feel ready to play better and gives them a boost of energy, like when you have a yummy snack before running around. It’s not something you should use all the time, but sometimes it helps them get back in the game!

title: How do physicists generate a stream of neutrons to fire in their experiments?
text: Okay, imagine neutrons are tiny, invisible balls that help scientists learn about the building blocks of everything around us. To make these balls, physicists use big machines called particle accelerators. Think of a particle accelerator like a super-fast slide for tiny particles. They take smaller particles, like protons (which are a bit like tiny marbles), and they speed them up really, really fast using lots of energy. When these fast protons smash into a special target, like a piece of metal or another kind of atom, they can break apart and create neutrons, along with other particles. Once the neutrons are made, scientists can guide them in a certain direction, kind of like using a vacuum to suck up dust and point it where you want! This way, they can fire the stream of neutrons at things they want to study, like atoms or materials, to learn more about how everything works.

title: Why does the bathroom get steamy when the water is well below the boiling point?
text: The bathroom gets steamy because when you take a hot shower or bath, the hot water makes some of the water turn into tiny little water droplets that float in the air, which we call steam. Even though the water isn’t boiling like when you see bubbles in a pot, it’s still warm enough to make some of it change into steam. This warm, wet air fills the bathroom and makes it feel steamy, like when you breathe out on a cold day and see your breath! So it's just the warm water making the air feel wet and cozy.

title: why do plastic wrappers tear much easier after an initial cut?
text: Okay, imagine you have a piece of paper, and you make a small cut in it. When you pull on the paper around that cut, it gets easier to rip because the cut makes a weak spot. It’s like if you started to tear a piece of candy wrapper from one side; once you get it started, it’s much easier to keep tearing it all the way around. The same thing happens with plastic wrappers! When you cut or poke a hole in them, it creates a little weak area, and that makes it easier for the plastic to tear apart from that spot. So, once you get that first cut, the rest of the wrapper just wants to follow along and tear easily!

title: How do words get mapped to concepts within the brain?
text: Okay, imagine your brain is like a big library, and every word is a book on a shelf. When you hear a word, like "dog," your brain quickly goes to the shelf where the "dog" book is kept. This book has pictures and stories about dogs, like how they bark and wag their tails. The more you learn about dogs, the more details and memories get added to that book. So, when you think of the word "dog," your brain pulls out that book and all the fun things you know about dogs come to mind! It’s like a treasure chest of ideas, and your brain knows exactly where to find each treasure when you need it!

title: Why can't Canadians watch certain American programs (like Saturday Night Live) online?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy that you really like, but your friend in another country can’t play with it. That’s kind of what happens with some TV shows. When a show like Saturday Night Live is made, the people who created it sell it to different countries. Sometimes, they only sell it to America, so that means only people in America can watch it online. It’s like having special permission to play with that toy. So, in Canada, they might not have the same permission to watch certain American shows online, and that’s why they can’t see them like you can!

title: how does left-cardiac hypertrophy lead to cardiac arrhythmias?
text: Okay, imagine your heart is like a big, strong balloon that pumps blood to your body. Sometimes, if you push too hard on the balloon, it gets bigger and thicker so it can handle the pressure. This is what happens with left-cardiac hypertrophy, where the left side of your heart becomes thick because it's working really hard, maybe from things like high blood pressure. When the heart gets thicker, it can make it harder for the electricity that helps it beat to travel smoothly. It’s like if you had a toy train that usually goes around a track, but if the track gets all bumpy, the train might get stuck or go off the track. This can make the heart beat too fast, too slow, or in a weird way, which we call arrhythmias. So, when the heart gets thicker and heavier, it can cause problems with how it beats, just like a toy train can have problems on a bumpy track!

title: How do bacteria develop resistance to drugs but not to the human immune system?
text: Okay, imagine you have a superhero team that fights bad guys, and the bad guys are bacteria. Sometimes, these bacteria find a way to wear disguises or get superpowers that help them escape from the superheroes we send to fight them, like when they get used to medicine called antibiotics. This is like when a bad guy learns how to dodge the superhero's punches! But when it comes to our body's immune system, which is also like a superhero team, bacteria can't just wear a disguise. Our immune system is really good at figuring out how to fight them in different ways, kind of like a superhero that always has a new trick up their sleeve. So, while bacteria can learn to dodge the medicine, they can’t trick our immune system as easily!

title: Can mass abortion eradicate inherited genetic defects?
text: Okay, imagine that inside our bodies, we have tiny instructions called genes that tell us how to grow and what we look like, like a recipe for making cookies. Sometimes, there are mistakes in these instructions that can make people sick or give them problems. Now, if a lot of babies who might have these mistakes are not born, it could mean fewer people with those problems in the future. But it’s important to remember that not everyone with a genetic problem is sick or unhappy, and some people might even have special talents because of their genes. Instead of just stopping babies from being born, scientists and doctors are also trying to figure out how to fix the mistakes in the genes or help people live better lives with them. So, while mass abortion might reduce some inherited problems, it doesn’t really solve everything, and there are other ways to help people too!

title: Why athletes in the same Olympic event don't use the exact same equipmrnt?
text: Athletes in the same Olympic event don't use the exact same equipment because everyone has different preferences and needs, just like how some kids like different colors or toys. For example, a runner might choose shoes that feel super comfy for their feet, while another runner prefers shoes that are really light. Some swimmers might use different types of goggles that fit their faces better. Plus, each athlete can be a little different in size and shape, so using equipment that feels right for them can help them do their best. It’s like how you might pick your favorite crayon to draw with – everyone has their own special way that helps them shine!

title: How does every $1 Billion dollars spent in commercial construction add $3.4 Billion to the GDP?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of building blocks, and you decide to build a really cool fort. When you spend $1 to buy some blocks, you're not just getting those blocks for yourself. You're also helping the person who sold you the blocks because they get to use that money to buy more things, like food or toys. Now, when you build your fort, you might need help from your friends, so you pay them some of that money too. They then use that money to buy their own things. This keeps going on, and each time someone gets paid, they spend that money on something else, like ice cream or a movie. So, when we say that spending $1 billion on building something adds $3.4 billion to the GDP, it means that all those people are using that money to buy things and pay others, which helps the whole economy grow bigger and bigger, just like your fort getting bigger with more blocks!

title: Why do some people develop a mental illness during childhood instead of when they are older? Are there different factors involved?
text: Some people get sick in their feelings or thinking when they're kids because their brains are still growing and changing a lot. Imagine your brain like a big puzzle that is still being put together. Sometimes, things in life, like feeling really sad, scared, or having big changes, can make it hard for the puzzle pieces to fit right. Other times, if someone in their family has had these feelings before, it can make it more likely for a kid to feel that way too, kind of like catching a cold. So, things like family, friends, and what’s happening around them can all mix together and cause some kids to have these tough feelings early on instead of later when they’re bigger.

title: What are the side effects of having a currency with a real, fixed value? Is such a thing even possible?
text: Okay, imagine you have a toy that you really love, and it always costs the same number of your toy coins, like 5 coins. If the toy never changes its price, that’s like having a currency with a fixed value. Now, if everyone knows the toy will always cost 5 coins, they might not want to trade their other toys for those coins because they can’t buy more toys with them if prices go up. This can make trading harder. Also, if something happens, like a lot of people suddenly want that toy, the price should go up, but because it can’t, people might get upset and stop trading. So, having a currency with a fixed value can make things feel safe, but it can also make it hard to keep up with what people want and need! And yes, while it’s possible to have a currency with a fixed value, it can be tricky to keep it working well in the real world.

title: For fires as extreme as those occurring in California currently, how are these fires put out?
text: When there are really big fires, like the ones in California, firefighters have to use a lot of different ways to put them out. First, they might use big trucks with water hoses to spray water on the flames, kind of like using a garden hose to water plants. Sometimes, they also use planes and helicopters to drop water or special stuff that helps stop the fire. Firefighters also build small ditches or clear away trees and bushes around the fire, so there’s nothing left for the fire to burn. This is called creating a firebreak. They work really hard and can be in tough places, like mountains or forests, to help keep people and animals safe. It’s like a big team of heroes trying to stop the fire from spreading!

title: what's the difference between a $4 bottle of honey and a $15 jar of honey? What am I missing out on by buying the cheaper honey?
text: Okay, imagine honey is like a special treat made by bees. The $4 bottle of honey might be from lots of different flowers and made in a big factory. It’s kind of like the fast food of honey; it’s sweet and okay, but not super special. The $15 jar of honey usually comes from one kind of flower and is made by bees that are really well cared for. This honey might taste yummier and have more good stuff in it. So, when you buy the more expensive honey, you’re getting a special flavor and quality that the cheaper honey might not have. It's like choosing between a regular cupcake and a fancy cupcake with sprinkles and a cherry on top!

title: Remember when point and shoot cameras had a flash that made a high pitched tone when you turned it on? What made that sound? What was the purpose of that sound?
text: Sure! When you turned on a point-and-shoot camera and it made that high-pitched sound, it was like a little helper saying, "Hey, I'm ready to take pictures!" Inside the camera, there was a small part called a capacitor that stored energy to make the flash work. When you turned on the camera, the capacitor would charge up and make that sound to let you know it was getting ready to take a bright picture. So, the sound was just a friendly reminder that your camera was ready to snap a photo!

title: Why is there a wait period between when we eat and when we feel full?
text: When you eat, your tummy starts to fill up with food like a balloon filling with air. But it takes a little time for your tummy to send a message to your brain saying, "Hey, I'm full now!" This happens because your brain needs to figure out how much food is in your tummy and that takes a bit of time. So, if you eat too fast, you might not feel full right away and could eat more than you really need. That's why it's good to eat slowly and give your body a chance to let you know when you've had enough!

title: Why does salt and ice make it colder, but at the same time when you put salt down on snow, it melts it faster?
text: Okay, so imagine you have some ice and you sprinkle salt on it. The salt is like a magic helper that makes the ice melt faster, but it also makes things colder at the same time! Here’s how it works: when salt is added to ice, it breaks the ice down and helps it turn into water. This melting process takes a bit of energy, and that energy comes from the ice itself, which makes it colder. So, the salt helps the ice turn into water quickly, and while it does that, it makes the area feel super cold! It's like when you eat ice cream too fast and your head feels cold; the salt is just making the ice melt and the coldness from the ice spreads around!

title: how do we make different notes when we whistle?
text: When we whistle, we make different notes by changing how we shape our mouths and how hard we blow air. Imagine your mouth is like a little music box! If you make your lips tight and blow harder, you get a higher note, like a little bird chirping. If you make your lips wider and blow softer, you get a lower note, like a big cow mooing. So, by playing with the shape of your mouth and the strength of your breath, you can create all sorts of different sounds!

title: How Blue Whales eat/swallow and what would happen if a human was diving nearby?
text: Okay, so blue whales are the biggest animals on Earth, and they eat tiny little shrimp called krill. They swim with their mouths open and take in a lot of water and krill at the same time. Then, they close their mouths and push the water out through special filters called baleen, which catch the krill inside. Now, if a human was diving nearby, the whale wouldn't really notice them because it's looking for krill, not people. But, blue whales are so big that if they accidentally swam close to the diver while opening their mouth, it could be a little dangerous! The whale might not mean to, but it could accidentally hurt the diver. So, it’s important for people to be careful and keep a good distance from such giant animals!

title: What is a laser printer doing when it is making all those noises but not printing?
text: Okay, imagine a laser printer is like a robot that draws pictures on paper. When it makes noises but isn’t printing, it’s like the robot is getting ready to draw but is having some trouble. It might be moving its little arms and parts around, trying to find the right place to grab the paper or make sure everything inside is working correctly. Sometimes it might be trying to clean itself or fix a problem, like if the paper is stuck or if it needs more ink. So, it’s busy making sounds and getting everything ready before it can finally print your picture!

title: Which countries don't rely on the US for their internet?
text: Okay! So, imagine the internet is like a big playground where kids from all over the world can play together. Some kids, like those in the U.S., have their own special swings and slides that help them play. But there are other kids in different countries, like China, Russia, and India, who have their own swings and slides too! They can still play on the playground without using the U.S. swings. So, these countries have their own ways to connect to the internet and don't need the U.S. to help them play. They can still share toys and games with other kids, but they do it using their own special paths.

title: Is time is relative to your reference frame, how can the universe be described as 13 billions years old?
text: Okay, imagine you're at a birthday party with a big clock on the wall that shows the time. Now, if you're playing on the swings, time feels like it's going super fast because you're having so much fun! But if you're waiting in line for cake, it feels like time is crawling because you're so excited. So, time can feel different depending on what you're doing. Now, scientists figured out that time can actually change depending on how fast you're moving or how close you are to something really heavy, like a planet. This is called "time being relative." But when we say the universe is about 13 billion years old, we're using a special kind of clock that everyone can agree on, like a big, cosmic clock that measures time in a way that doesn't change no matter where you are or how fast you're going. So, even though time can feel different in different situations, the 13 billion years is like a universal birthday cake that everyone shares, and it helps us understand how old everything is in the universe!

title: Why are nutritional facts based on a 2,000 calorie diet when that's well below the average for humans?
text: Nutritional facts on food labels are based on a 2,000 calorie diet because it's like a starting point or a middle ground that most people can use to understand how much they should eat. Imagine if you were playing a game and needed a score to help you know if you were doing well—2,000 calories is that score! Some people eat more and some eat less, but 2,000 calories helps everyone see how much of things like vitamins and minerals they should try to get in their food. It’s like having a common way to talk about food so everyone can understand it better, even if some people need more or less.

title: Why does a hot shower make my skin dry?
text: When you take a hot shower, the warm water feels nice and cozy, but it can also take away some of the special oils that keep your skin soft and smooth. These oils are like a little shield that protects your skin from getting too dry. So, when you use really hot water, it washes away those oils and makes your skin feel dry and sometimes even itchy afterward. It’s kind of like how your toys can get dusty if you don’t clean them, but if you clean them too much, they might lose their shine! To keep your skin happy, it’s better to use warm water instead of super hot water and maybe put on some lotion afterward to help keep it soft.

title: Besides Humans are there any cases of two different species hunting together?
text: Yes, there are some animals that work together to hunt, even if they are different species! One cool example is when a group of dolphins and a bunch of birds team up. The dolphins will swim around and push fish to the surface of the water, and then the birds fly down to catch the fish that jump out. They help each other out! Another example is when some ants and aphids work together. The ants protect the aphids from other animals, and in return, the aphids give the ants a sweet juice to eat. So, just like friends can work together, different animals can also team up to find food!

title: Why is almost every country in debt?
text: Okay! Imagine if you wanted to buy a really cool toy, but you didn't have enough money saved up. So, you ask your parents for some money to help you buy it, and you promise to give it back later. That's kind of like what countries do when they borrow money. They need money for things like building roads, schools, and hospitals, and sometimes they don't have enough saved up, so they borrow from other countries or banks. They do this so they can help their people have better lives now, even if they owe money that they will pay back later. Just like you might pay your parents back with your allowance, countries plan to pay back the money they borrowed over time. So, almost every country is in debt because they borrow money to make things better for everyone!

title: How do people see beauty? For example, what makes a rose beautiful but a Cactus not?
text: Okay, so think of beauty like a fun game where everyone has different favorite things! A rose is often seen as beautiful because it has soft, colorful petals and a nice smell, like when you see a pretty picture that makes you smile. It’s like a happy flower! On the other hand, a cactus is different; it’s spiky and not soft, so some people might think it’s not as pretty. But here’s the cool part: beauty can change depending on who’s looking! Some people might think cactuses are really cool or interesting because they’re tough and can live in super hot places. So, what makes something beautiful can be about how it looks, how it makes us feel, and even what we like!

title: What would happen if all the layers of the Earth's core cooled and hardened?
text: Okay, imagine the Earth is like a big, delicious cake with lots of layers. The inside of the cake, which is the Earth's core, is super hot and gooey, kind of like melted chocolate. If all the layers of the core cooled down and became hard like ice, the cake would change a lot! First, the Earth would lose some of its magnetic shield that helps protect us from bad stuff from space, like harmful rays. Without that shield, it might be harder for us to live safely on the surface. Also, the movement of the Earth would change because the hot, gooey parts help keep things moving and make volcanoes and earthquakes happen. So, if everything turned hard, the Earth would be a very different place, and it might not be as comfy for us to live on anymore!

title: As carbon chain size increases, molecule become less and less water soluble. Why?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big, fluffy blanket made of soft teddy bear fur. If you try to put that big blanket in a small cup of water, it won't fit and won't get wet very well, right? Now think of a tiny, smooth pebble; it can easily fit in the water and get wet all over. Molecules are kind of like that! When the carbon chain gets bigger, it’s like adding more and more fluffy parts to the blanket. These fluffy parts don’t like to hang out with water because they want to stick to each other instead. So, the bigger the carbon chain, the less it wants to mix with water, just like how the big blanket doesn’t fit in the cup!

title: Why do so few people live in the Canadian Territories like the Yukon but Alaska has a much larger population with similar climate and geography?
text: Okay, imagine you have two big ice cream cones, one is in Canada called the Yukon and the other is in America called Alaska. Both cones are super cold and have lots of snow, but they are different in some ways! In Alaska, there are more fun things for people to do, like jobs, schools, and shops. It's like having lots of toys and games to play with! The U.S. also helps people with things like roads and airports to get around easier. In Yukon, there are fewer of those things, so it's more like having just a few toys, which makes it harder for people to want to live there. Plus, Alaska is bigger and has more cities where people can live together, while Yukon is smaller and has more empty space. So, even though both places are cold, Alaska has more people because it feels more like home with more things to enjoy!

title: How do brands manufacturing non-concentrated, natural fruit juice keep the taste constant?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons with lots of different colors. Sometimes, when you color with them, the colors look a little different, right? Well, fruit juice can be like that too! When people make juice from fruits, sometimes the taste can change depending on the weather or how ripe the fruits are. So, to keep the juice tasting the same every time you drink it, the juice makers mix different fruits together, kind of like mixing crayons, to get the best taste. They also have special ways to check the taste and might add a tiny bit of something to make it sweeter or yummier without using fake stuff. This way, when you open a bottle of juice, it tastes just like you expect every single time!

title: If all human cells replace themselves every 7 years, why can scars remain on you body your entire life?
text: Okay, imagine your body is like a big LEGO castle. Every few years, you take out some old LEGO blocks and put in new ones to keep the castle looking fresh. Most of the blocks, or cells, will change and get replaced, but some special blocks, like the ones that make scars, are a bit different. When you get a cut, the body sends special blocks to fix it, and they stick together really tightly to make a strong wall. These scar blocks don’t get replaced like the other ones because they are made to be tough and protect the area. So even though many of your cells change every 7 years, those special scar blocks can stay there for a long time, and that’s why you can see scars on your skin for your whole life!

title: Why is there a "feels like" temperature? Shouldn't that just be the temperature?
text: Okay, imagine you're outside on a hot sunny day. The thermometer might say it's 85 degrees, but if there's a big wind blowing, it might feel a lot cooler, like 75 degrees. That's because the wind is taking away the warm air from your skin. The "feels like" temperature is a way to tell you how the weather feels to our bodies, not just what the thermometer says. It can change because of things like wind, humidity (which is like how much water is in the air), and how sunny it is. So sometimes it feels hotter or colder than the number we see!

title: What is Pi-Hole, what does it do?
text: Pi-hole is like a superhero for your internet! Imagine you have a big box of toys, but some of them are really annoying and just make noise all the time. Pi-hole helps you get rid of those annoying toys! When you use Pi-hole, it blocks unwanted ads and pesky things that pop up when you're watching videos or playing games online. So, when you're browsing the internet, it helps make everything faster and cleaner by stopping those annoying ads from showing up. It's like having a magic shield that protects your computer and makes your online fun even better!

title: . How did climate change become a partisan issue?
text: Okay, imagine you have a big box of crayons, and some friends want to use the red crayon for drawing a pretty sun, while others think using the blue crayon for a rainy sky is better.
